Chapter 1. Minimaxity.

Other Sections: Chapter 2, Chapter 3, Chapter 4 - Part 1, Chapter 4 - Part 2


Background

  • Suppose we observe data W∈WW\in\mathcal{W}W∈W from a distribution PPP belongings to a model P\mathcal{P}P.

    • We'll be most interested in the special case where P=QnP=Q^nP=Qn, so that WWW consists of nnn iid draws from QQQ.

  • Based on w∈Ww\in Ww∈W, we take an action aaa in the action space A\mathcal{A}A.

    • We'll consider a collection of decision rules T:W→AT: \mathcal{W} \to \mathcal{A}T:W→A.

  • The quality of an action is judged by a loss function L:A×P→RL: \mathcal{A}\times \mathcal{P} \to \mathbb{R}L:A×P→R.

    • The quality of a decision rule TTT will be judged via the risk:
      R(T,P)=∫L(T(w),P)dP(w).R(T,P) = \int L(T(w), P) dP(w).R(T,P)=∫L(T(w),P)dP(w).

Example 1: Point estimation.

The objective is to estimate Ψ(P)∈R\Psi(P) \in \mathbb{R}Ψ(P)∈R.

  • E.g., P=QnP=Q^nP=Qn and Ψ(P)=∫x dQ(x)\Psi(P) = \int x \, dQ(x)Ψ(P)=∫xdQ(x).
  • E.g., P=QnP=Q^nP=Qn and Ψ(P)=EQ[Y∣X=x0]\Psi(P) = E_Q[Y \mid X=x_0]Ψ(P)=EQ​[Y∣X=x0​].

If L(a,P)={a−Φ(P)}2L(a,P) = \{ a-\Phi(P) \}^2L(a,P)={a−Φ(P)}2, then
R(T,P)=∫{T(w)−Ψ(P)}2dP(w)R(T,P) = \int \{ T(w) - \Psi(P) \}^2 dP(w)R(T,P)=∫{T(w)−Ψ(P)}2dP(w)

is the mean-squared error (MSE).


Example 2: Estimating a regression function.

  • We observe nnn iid copies of (X,Y)∼Q(X,Y) \sim Q(X,Y)∼Q and we wish to estimate
    fQ:x↦EQ[Y∣X=x].f_Q:x \mapsto E_Q[Y\mid X=x].fQ​:x↦EQ​[Y∣X=x].

  • The action space is a collection of functions mapping from X\mathcal{X}X to R\mathbb{R}R.

  • We might use an integrated squared error loss,
    L(a,P)=∫{a(x)−fQ(x)}2dν(x).L(a,P) = \int \{ a(x) - f_Q(x) \}^2 d\nu(x).L(a,P)=∫{a(x)−fQ​(x)}2dν(x).

    Here, ν\nuν is either some chosen reference measure on X\mathcal{X}X — e.g., Lebesgue — or ν\nuν could be the marginal distribution of XXX when (X,Y)∼Q(X,Y) \sim Q(X,Y)∼Q.

    • The corresponding risk is called the mean integrated squared error (MISE).

Recall from STAT 581 that the performance of a rule TTT can be judged by its maximal risk:
sup⁡P∈PR(T,P).\sup_{P\in\mathcal{P}} R(T,P).P∈Psup​R(T,P).

A minimax estimator (decision rule) minimizes the maximal risk.

Challenge: Deriving a minimax estimator is often an intractable problem\red{\textbf{intractable problem}}intractable problem.

Minimax rate optimality

High level (simplified setting): If the minimax risk satisfies the following for some C1>0C_1>0C1​>0 and α>0\alpha>0α>0:
inf⁡Tsup⁡QnR(T,Qn)⏟“minimax risk"=C1n−α\underbrace{\inf_{T} \sup_{Q^n} R(T, Q^n)}_{\blue{\text{``minimax risk"}}} = C_1 n^{-\alpha}“minimax risk"Tinf​Qnsup​R(T,Qn)​​=C1​n−α

then we will call an estimator sequence (Tn)n=1∞(T_n)_{n=1}^{\infty}(Tn​)n=1∞​ minimax rate optimal if
sup⁡QnR(Tn,Qn)=C2n−α\sup_{Q^n} R(T_n, Q^n) = C_2 n^{-\alpha}Qnsup​R(Tn​,Qn)=C2​n−α

for some C2>0C_2>0C2​>0.

Note: TV(P1,P2)=1−∫min⁡(p1(x),p2(x))dν(x)TV(P_1, P_2) = 1-\int \min (p_1(x), p_2(x)) d\nu(x)TV(P1​,P2​)=1−∫min(p1​(x),p2​(x))dν(x) is the total variation, where p1=dP1dνp_1 = \frac{dP_1}{d\nu}p1​=dνdP1​​

More detail

Because we can't typically derive a minimax estimator, we'll instead look to derive estimators with a minimax-optimal rate.

For now, we'll consider cases where P=QnP=Q^nP=Qn. For each nnn, let Tn\mathcal{T}_nTn​ denote the collection of allowable decision rules at sample size nnn. In many problems, the risk is always nonnegative and
inf⁡T∈Tnsup⁡Q∈QR(T,Qn)⟶n→∞0,\inf_{T\in\mathcal{T}_n} \sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}} R(T, Q^n) \stackrel{n\to\infty}{\longrightarrow} 0,T∈Tn​inf​Q∈Qsup​R(T,Qn)⟶n→∞​0,

i.e., the problem is not impossible. We'll focus on these problems here.

Definition. A sequence of rules (Tn)n=1∞(T_n)_{n=1}^{\infty}(Tn​)n=1∞​ is called minimax rate optimal if
lim⁡n→∞inf⁡T∈Tnsup⁡Q∈QR(T,Qn)sup⁡Q∈QR(Tn,Qn)>0.[n−1n−1/2=n−1/2→0](★)\lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{\displaystyle\footnotesize\inf_{T\in\mathcal{T}_n} \sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}} R(T,Q^n)}{\displaystyle\footnotesize\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}} R(T_n, Q^n)} > 0. \hspace{3em} \left[ \scriptsize \purple{\frac{n^{-1}}{n^{-1/2}} = n^{-1/2} \to 0} \right] \tag{$\orange{\bigstar}$}n→∞lim​Q∈Qsup​R(Tn​,Qn)T∈Tn​inf​Q∈Qsup​R(T,Qn)​>0.[n−1/2n−1​=n−1/2→0](★)

Put another way
sup⁡Q∈QR(Tn,Qn)=O(inf⁡T∈Tnsup⁡Q∈QR(T,Qn)).\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}} R(T_n, Q^n) = O \left( \inf_{T\in\mathcal{T}_n} \sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}} R(T, Q^n) \right) .Q∈Qsup​R(Tn​,Qn)=O(T∈Tn​inf​Q∈Qsup​R(T,Qn)).


Problem: We can't typically derive the numerator or denominator of (★)(\orange{\bigstar})(★)!

Solution: Find bounds on them.

Later in thise course, we'll fine (Un)n=1∞(U_n)_{n=1}^{\infty}(Un​)n=1∞​ so that
sup⁡Q∈QR(Tn,Qn)≤Un\sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}} R(T_n, Q^n) \leq U_nQ∈Qsup​R(Tn​,Qn)≤Un​

for interesting sequences of estimators (Tn)n=1∞(T_n)_{n=1}^{\infty}(Tn​)n=1∞​.

In this chapter, we'll find (Ln)n=1∞(L_n)_{n=1}^{\infty}(Ln​)n=1∞​ such that
inf⁡T∈Tnsup⁡Q∈QR(T,Qn)≥ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣Ln⏟lower boundon the minimaxrisk ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ ⁣.\inf_{T\in\mathcal{T}_n} \sup_{Q\in\mathcal{Q}} R(T, Q^n) \geq \!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\underbrace{L_n}_{\substack{\text{lower bound} \\ \text{on the minimax} \\ \text{risk}}}\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!.T∈Tn​inf​Q∈Qsup​R(T,Qn)≥lower boundon the minimaxrisk​Ln​​​.

Once we have these two bounds,
inf⁡T∈Tnsup⁡QR(T,Qn)sup⁡QR(Tn,Qn)≥LnUn.\frac{\displaystyle\footnotesize\inf_{T\in\mathcal{T}_n} \sup_{Q} R(T,Q^n)}{\displaystyle\footnotesize\sup_{Q} R(T_n, Q^n)} \geq \frac{L_n}{U_n}.Qsup​R(Tn​,Qn)T∈Tn​inf​Qsup​R(T,Qn)​≥Un​Ln​​.

Hence, to show (★)(\bigstar)(★), it's enough to show
lim inf⁡n→∞LnUn>0.\liminf_{n\to\infty} \frac{L_n}{U_n} >0.n→∞liminf​Un​Ln​​>0.

In the remainder of this chapter, we'll focus on deriving lower bounds LLL on the minimax risk:
inf⁡Tsup⁡PR(T,P)≥L.\inf_{T} \sup_{P} R(T,P) \geq L.Tinf​Psup​R(T,P)≥L.

Recall from STAT 581: For any prior Π\PiΠ on P\mathcal{P}P, the Bayes risk of a decision rule TTT is given by
r(T,Π)=∫R(T,P) dΠ(P).r(T, \Pi) = \int R(T,P) \, d\Pi(P).r(T,Π)=∫R(T,P)dΠ(P).

Lemma. For any decision rule TTT, (PPP taken over all possible distributions and Π\PiΠ is taken over all possible priors).
sup⁡PR(T,P)≥sup⁡Πr(T,Π).\sup_{P} R(T,P) \geq \sup_{\Pi} r(T,\Pi).Psup​R(T,P)≥Πsup​r(T,Π).


Proof. For any Π\PiΠ, the fact that supremums over P\mathcal{P}P are lower bounded by expectations over distributions supported on P\mathcal{P}P yields
sup⁡PR(T,P)⏟maximal risk≥r(T,Π)⏟Bayes risk.\underbrace{\sup_{P} R(T, P)}_{\text{maximal risk}} \geq \underbrace{r(T,\Pi)}_{\text{Bayes risk}}.maximal riskPsup​R(T,P)​​≥Bayes riskr(T,Π)​​.

Taking a supremum over Π\PiΠ on both sides gives the result. □\hspace{0.5em} \square□


Theorem. For any decision problem,
inf⁡Tsup⁡PR(T,P)⏟“minimax risk"≥sup⁡Πinf⁡Tr(T,Π)⏟“Bayes risk underleast favorable prior".\underbrace{\inf_{T} \sup_{P} R(T,P)}_{\text{``minimax risk"}} \geq \underbrace{\sup_\Pi \inf_T r(T,\Pi)}_{\substack{\text{``Bayes risk under} \\ \text{least favorable prior"}}}.“minimax risk"Tinf​Psup​R(T,P)​​≥“Bayes risk underleast favorable prior"​Πsup​Tinf​r(T,Π)​​.


Proof. The max-min inequality yields that
inf⁡Tsup⁡Πr(T,Π)≥sup⁡Πinf⁡Tr(T,Π).\inf_T \sup_\Pi r(T,\Pi) \geq \sup_\Pi \inf_T r(T,\Pi).Tinf​Πsup​r(T,Π)≥Πsup​Tinf​r(T,Π).

Combining this with the preceding lemma yields the desired result. □\hspace{0.5em} \square□


The main consequence of this theorem that we use in this chapter is the following:

    for any prior Π,inf⁡Tsup⁡PR(T,P)≥inf⁡Tr(T,Π)(1)\text{for any prior }\Pi, \inf_T \sup_P R(T, P) \geq \inf_T r(T,\Pi) \tag{1}for any prior Π,Tinf​Psup​R(T,P)≥Tinf​r(T,Π)(1)

Method # 1 for deriving minimax lower bounds

Theorem (Le Cam). Let RRR be a risk function defined according to some nonnegative loss LLL. For any P1,P2∈PP_1, P_2 \in\mathcal{P}P1​,P2​∈P,
inf⁡Tsup⁡PR(T,P)≥12d(P1,P2)∥p1∧p2∥1≥14d(P1,P2)exp⁡[−KL(P1,P2)]\begin{align*} \inf_T \sup_P R(T,P) &\geq \frac{1}{2} \blue{d(P_1, P_2)} \red{\Vert p_1 \wedge p_2 \Vert_1} \\ &\geq \frac{1}{4} \blue{d(P_1, P_2)} \exp [-\green{KL(P_1,P_2)}] \end{align*}Tinf​Psup​R(T,P)​≥21​d(P1​,P2​)∥p1​∧p2​∥1​≥41​d(P1​,P2​)exp[−KL(P1​,P2​)]​

where
d(P1,P2)=inf⁡a∈A[L(a,P1)+L(a,P2)],(discrepancy)∥p1∧p2∥1=∫min⁡{dP1dν(w),dP2dν(w)},(testing affinity)KL(P1,P2)={∫log⁡[dP1dP2(w)]dP1(w),if P1≪P2,+∞,otherwise(KL divergence)\begin{align*} \blue{d(P_1,P_2)} &= \inf_{a\in\mathcal{A}} [L(a,P_1) + L(a,P_2)], \hspace{7.958em}\text{(discrepancy)} \\ \red{\Vert p_1 \wedge p_2 \Vert_1} &= \int \min \left\{ \frac{dP_1}{d\nu}(w), \frac{dP_2}{d\nu}(w)\right\}, \hspace{6.3em} \text{(testing affinity)} \\ \green{KL(P_1,P_2)} &= \begin{cases} \int \log \left[ \frac{dP_1}{dP_2} (w) \right] dP_1(w), & \text{if } P_1 \ll P_2, \\ +\infty, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} \hspace{2em} \text{(KL divergence)} \end{align*}d(P1​,P2​)∥p1​∧p2​∥1​KL(P1​,P2​)​=a∈Ainf​[L(a,P1​)+L(a,P2​)],(discrepancy)=∫min{dνdP1​​(w),dνdP2​​(w)},(testing affinity)={∫log[dP2​dP1​​(w)]dP1​(w),+∞,​if P1​≪P2​,otherwise​(KL divergence)​


Remark 1. Understanding the discrepancy.

We'll look at the discrepancy in two special cases.

  1. Point estimation with squared error loss:
    We want to estimate Ψ(P)∈R\Psi(P)\in\mathbb{R}Ψ(P)∈R and
    L(a,P)=[a−Ψ(P)]2.L(a,P) = [a - \Psi(P)]^2.L(a,P)=[a−Ψ(P)]2. A little calculus shows that
    d(P1,P2)=inf⁡a∈R[L(a,P1)+L(a,P2)]=12[Ψ(P1)−Ψ(P2)]2\begin{align*} d(P_1,P_2) &= \inf_{a\in\mathbb{R}} [L(a,P_1) + L(a,P_2)] \\ &= \frac{1}{2} [\Psi(P_1) - \Psi(P_2)]^2 \end{align*}d(P1​,P2​)​=a∈Rinf​[L(a,P1​)+L(a,P2​)]=21​[Ψ(P1​)−Ψ(P2​)]2​

  2. Estimating a function with respect to the integrated squared error:

    Here, P=QnP=Q^nP=Qn, the action space is a convex subset of the space functions mapping from X\mathcal{X}X to R\mathbb{R}R, and
    L(a,P)=∫[a(x)−fQ(x)]2dν(x).(ν is a fixed measure)L(a, P) = \int [a(x) - f_Q(x)]^2 d\nu(x). \hspace{2em} (\nu \text{ is a fixed measure})L(a,P)=∫[a(x)−fQ​(x)]2dν(x).(ν is a fixed measure)

    In this case, you can show that
    d(P1,P2)=12∫[fQ1(x)−fQ2(x)]2dν(x),d(P_1,P_2) = \frac{1}{2} \int [f_{Q_1}(x) - f_{Q_2}(x)]^2 d\nu(x),d(P1​,P2​)=21​∫[fQ1​​(x)−fQ2​​(x)]2dν(x),

    where P1=Q1nP_1 = Q_1^nP1​=Q1n​ and P2=Q2nP_2 = Q_2^nP2​=Q2n​.


Remark 2. Understanding testing affinity.

Statistically, we can show that, give a draw WWW from PjP_jPj​, j∈{1,2}j\in\{ 1,2 \}j∈{1,2} unknown, the difficulty of identifying jjj is characterized by ∥p1∧p2∥1\Vert p_1 \wedge p_2 \Vert_1∥p1​∧p2​∥1​.

Note that
∥p1∧p2∥1=∫min⁡{p1(w),p2(w)}dν(w).\purple{ \Vert p_1 \wedge p_2 \Vert_1 = \int \min \{ p_1(w), p_2(w) \} d \nu(w)}.∥p1​∧p2​∥1​=∫min{p1​(w),p2​(w)}dν(w).


  • Consider a test T:W→{1,2}T: \mathcal{W} \to \{ 1,2 \}T:W→{1,2}.

    We'll quantify performance of TTT via misclassification error:
    E(T)=EP1[I{T(W)=2}]⏟error under P1+EP2[I{T(W)=1}]⏟error under P2.\mathcal{E}(T) = \underbrace{E_{P_1}[I\{ T(W) = 2 \}]}_{\text{error under } P_1} + \underbrace{E_{P_2}[I\{ T(W) = 1 \}]}_{\text{error under } P_2}.E(T)=error under P1​EP1​​[I{T(W)=2}]​​+error under P2​EP2​​[I{T(W)=1}]​​.

    Observe that, for any TTT,
    E(T)=∫[p1(w)I{T(w)=2}+p2(w)I{T(w)=1}]dν(w)≥∫min⁡{p1(w),p2(w)}[I{T(w)=2}+I{T(w)=1}⏟=1]dν(w)=∥p1∧p2∥1.\begin{align*} \mathcal{E}(T) &= \int [p_1(w) I\{ T(w) = 2 \} + p_2(w) I\{ T(w) = 1 \}] d\nu(w) \\ &\geq \int \min \{ p_1(w), p_2(w) \} [\underbrace{I\{ T(w) = 2 \} + I\{ T(w) = 1 \}}_{\blue{=1}}] d\nu(w) \\ &= \Vert p_1 \wedge p_2 \Vert_1. \end{align*}E(T)​=∫[p1​(w)I{T(w)=2}+p2​(w)I{T(w)=1}]dν(w)≥∫min{p1​(w),p2​(w)}[=1I{T(w)=2}+I{T(w)=1}​​]dν(w)=∥p1​∧p2​∥1​.​

    The lower bound is achieved by
    T⋆(w)=arg max⁡jpj(w).T^\star(w) = \argmax_{j} p_j(w).T⋆(w)=jargmax​pj​(w).

    Note: E(T⋆)=∥p1∧p2∥1\blue{\mathcal{E}(T^\star) = \Vert p_1 \wedge p_2 \Vert_1}E(T⋆)=∥p1​∧p2​∥1​.


Remark 3. (Not responsible for knowing this in this course.) ∥p1∧p2∥1=1−TV(P1,P2)\Vert p_1 \wedge p_2 \Vert_1 = 1 - TV(P_1,P_2)∥p1​∧p2​∥1​=1−TV(P1​,P2​), where
TV(P1,P2)=sup⁡A∣P1(A)−P2(A)∣.TV(P_1, P_2) = \sup_A |P_1(A) - P_2(A)|.TV(P1​,P2​)=Asup​∣P1​(A)−P2​(A)∣.



Proof (Le Cam). Let Π\PiΠ denote a uniform prior over {P1,P2}\{ P_1, P_2 \}{P1​,P2​}, that is, π(P1)=π(P2)=12\pi(P_1) = \pi(P_2) = \frac{1}{2}π(P1​)=π(P2​)=21​.

For any rule TTT,
r(T,Π)=∑j=12∫L(T(w),Pj) pj(w) dν(w)  π(Pj)=12∫[∑j=12L(T(w),Pj) pj(w)]dν(w)(since π(Pj)=12)≥12∫min⁡{p1(w),p2(w)}[∑j=12L(T(w),Pj)]dν(w)≥12∫min⁡{p1(w),p2(w)}[inf⁡a∈A∑j=12L(a,Pj)]⏟:=d(P1,P2)dν(w)=12d(P1,P2)∫min⁡{p1(w),p2(w)}dν(w)⏟:=∥p1∧p2∥1.\begin{align*} r(T, \Pi) &= \sum_{j=1}^{2} \int L(T(w), P_j) \, p_j(w)\, d\nu(w) \; \pi(P_j) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \int \left[ \sum_{j=1}^2 L(T(w), P_j) \, p_j(w)\right] d\nu(w) \hspace{2em} (\text{since } \pi(P_j) = \tfrac{1}{2}) \\ &\geq \frac{1}{2} \int \min \{ p_1(w), p_2(w) \} \left[ \sum_{j=1}^{2} L(T(w), P_j) \right] d\nu(w) \\ &\geq \frac{1}{2} \int \min \{ p_1(w), p_2(w) \} \underbrace{\left[ \inf_{a\in\mathcal{A}} \sum_{j=1}^{2} L(a, P_j)\right] }_{\blue{:= d(P_1, P_2)}} d\nu(w) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} d(P_1,P_2) \underbrace{\int \min \{ p_1(w), p_2(w) \} d\nu(w)}_{\blue{:= \Vert p_1 \wedge p_2 \Vert_1}}. \end{align*}r(T,Π)​=j=1∑2​∫L(T(w),Pj​)pj​(w)dν(w)π(Pj​)=21​∫[j=1∑2​L(T(w),Pj​)pj​(w)]dν(w)(since π(Pj​)=21​)≥21​∫min{p1​(w),p2​(w)}[j=1∑2​L(T(w),Pj​)]dν(w)≥21​∫min{p1​(w),p2​(w)}:=d(P1​,P2​)[a∈Ainf​j=1∑2​L(a,Pj​)]​​dν(w)=21​d(P1​,P2​):=∥p1​∧p2​∥1​∫min{p1​(w),p2​(w)}dν(w)​​.​

As TTT was arbitrary,
inf⁡Tr(T,Π)≥12d(P1,P2)∥p1∧p2∥1.\inf_{T} r(T,\Pi) \geq \frac{1}{2} d(P_1, P_2) \Vert p_1 \wedge p_2 \Vert_1.Tinf​r(T,Π)≥21​d(P1​,P2​)∥p1​∧p2​∥1​.

By Remark 1, this yields
inf⁡Tsup⁡PR(T,P)≥12d(P1,P2)∥p1∧p2∥1.\inf_T \sup_{P} R(T,P) \geq \frac{1}{2} d(P_1,P_2) \Vert p_1 \wedge p_2 \Vert_1.Tinf​Psup​R(T,P)≥21​d(P1​,P2​)∥p1​∧p2​∥1​.

The second bound of the theorem follows from problem 1 on homework 1.

Why we also need other lower bounding techniques

  • In certain cases, Le Cams method will provide a rate-optimal lower bound.

    • This is the case on problem 2 of homework 1, which concerns estimation of a smooth density at a point.

  • In other cases, Le Cam's method doesn't give a rate-optimal lower bound.

    • This is the case when the goal is to estimate a smooth regression function, with integrated squared error loss.

Theorem (Fano). Let RRR be a risk function defined according to some nonnegative loss LLL. For N≥3N\geq 3N≥3 and P1,P2,…,PN∈PP_1, P_2, \dots, P_N \in \mathcal{P}P1​,P2​,…,PN​∈P (the distributions contained in the model), define
η:=min⁡j≠kd(Pj,Pk)=min⁡j≠kinf⁡a[L(a,Pj)+L(a,Pk)],Pˉ:=1N∑j=1NPj,(uniform mixture of P1,P2,…,Pn )K:=max⁡j≠kKL(Pj,Pk).\begin{align*} \eta &:= \min_{j\neq k} d(P_j, P_k) = \min_{j\neq k} \inf_a [L(a, P_j) + L(a,P_k)], \\ \bar{P} &:= \frac{1}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} P_j, \hspace{2em} \orange{(\text{uniform mixture of $P_1,P_2,\dots,P_n$ })} \tag{$\orange{\bigstar}$}\\ K &:= \max_{j\neq k} \text{KL}(P_j, P_k). \end{align*}ηPˉK​:=j=kmin​d(Pj​,Pk​)=j=kmin​ainf​[L(a,Pj​)+L(a,Pk​)],:=N1​j=1∑N​Pj​,(uniform mixture of P1​,P2​,…,Pn​ ):=j=kmax​KL(Pj​,Pk​).​(★)​

(Note on (★)(\orange{\bigstar})(★) (see lecture notes screenshot))

It holds that
inf⁡Tsup⁡PR(T,P)≥η2[1−log⁡(2)+1N∑j=1NKL(Pj,Pˉ)log⁡(N)]≥η2[1−log⁡(2)+Klog⁡(N)]\begin{align*} \inf_T \sup_P R(T,P) &\geq \frac{\eta}{2} \left[ 1 - \frac{\log(2) + \frac{1}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \text{KL}(P_j, \bar{P})}{\log(N)} \right] \\ &\geq \frac{\purple{\eta}}{2} \left[ 1 - \frac{\log(2) + \blue{\Kappa}}{\log(\red{N})} \right] \end{align*}Tinf​Psup​R(T,P)​≥2η​[1−log(N)log(2)+N1​∑j=1N​KL(Pj​,Pˉ)​]≥2η​[1−log(N)log(2)+K​]​


Remark. The bound increases when:

  • N\red{N}N increases and η\purple{\eta}η, K\blue{\Kappa}K remain fixed.
  • K\blue{\Kappa}K decreases and η\purple{\eta}η, N\red{N}N remain fixed.
  • η\purple{\eta}η increases and K\blue{\Kappa}K, N\red{N}N remain fixed.

Moreover, adding a distribution to the set {P1,…,PN}\{ P_1,\dots,P_N \}{P1​,…,PN​} (i.e., increasing NNN) typically decreases η\etaη and increases K\KappaK.

Since sup⁡pR(T,P)≥r(T,Π)\sup_p R(T, P) \geq r(T,\Pi)supp​R(T,P)≥r(T,Π), this yields the first bound of the theorem statement.

The second bound follows from the fact that KL(Pj,⋅)\text{KL}(P_j, \cdot)KL(Pj​,⋅) is convex for all jjj. Indeed,
KL(Pj,Pˉ)=KL(Pj,1N∑i=1NPi)≤1N∑i=1NKL(Pj,Pi)≤max⁡i≠jKL(Pj,Pi).\begin{align*} \text{KL}(P_j, \bar{P}) &= \text{KL} \left( P_j, \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} P_i \right) \\ &\leq \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \text{KL}(P_j, P_i) \\ &\leq \max_{i\neq j} \text{KL}(P_j, P_i). \end{align*}KL(Pj​,Pˉ)​=KL(Pj​,N1​i=1∑N​Pi​)≤N1​i=1∑N​KL(Pj​,Pi​)≤i=jmax​KL(Pj​,Pi​).​


Example: Minimax lower bound for estimating a smooth regression function.

  • We observe (X1,Y1),…,(Xn,Yn)∼iidQ∈Q(X_1,Y_1), \dots, (X_n, Y_n) \stackrel{iid}{\sim} Q \in \mathcal{Q}(X1​,Y1​),…,(Xn​,Yn​)∼iidQ∈Q.

  • For each QQQ, the marginal distribution of XXX is U[0,1]U[0,1]U[0,1].

  • Moreover,
    Y∣X=x∼N(fQ(x),1)Y\mid X=x \sim N(f_Q(x), 1)Y∣X=x∼N(fQ​(x),1)

    where fQf_QfQ​ is smooth — in particular, fQ∈F(β,L)f_Q \in \mathcal{F}(\beta,L)fQ​∈F(β,L) with F(β,L)\mathcal{F}(\beta,L)F(β,L) denoting the Holder class:
    F(β,L):={f:f is ℓ-times differentiable and ∣fℓ(x1)−fℓ(x2)∣≤∣x1−x2∣β−ℓ for all x1,x2∈[0,1]}\mathcal{F}(\beta,L) := \left\{ f: f \text{ is } \ell \text{-times differentiable and } |f^{\ell}(x_1) - f^{\ell}(x_2) | \leq |x_1-x_2|^{\beta-\ell} \text{ for all } x_1, x_2 \in [0,1] \right\}F(β,L):={f:f is ℓ-times differentiable and ∣fℓ(x1​)−fℓ(x2​)∣≤∣x1​−x2​∣β−ℓ for all x1​,x2​∈[0,1]}

    where ℓ\ellℓ is the greatest integer strictly smaller than β\betaβ.

Note: A sufficient condition for a function fff to belong to F(β,L)\mathcal{F}(\beta,L)F(β,L) is that fff be (ℓ+1)(\ell+1)(ℓ+1)-times differentiable and
sup⁡x∣f(ℓ+1)(x)∣≤L.\sup_x \left| f^{(\ell+1)}(x) \right| \leq L.xsup​​f(ℓ+1)(x)​≤L.

Our objective is to estimate fQ(x)=EQ[Y∣X=x]f_Q(x) = E_Q[Y\mid X=x]fQ​(x)=EQ​[Y∣X=x]. Performance will be quantified via the integrated squared error:
L(a,P)=L(a,Qn)=∫01[a(x)−fQ(x)]2dx.L(a, P) = L(a, Q^n) = \int_{0}^{1} [a(x) - f_Q(x)]^2 dx.L(a,P)=L(a,Qn)=∫01​[a(x)−fQ​(x)]2dx.

We will derive a minimax lower bound for this regression function via Fano's method.

  • to do this, we must select a finite set P:={P1,…,PN}⊆P\mathcal{P} := \{ P_1,\dots,P_N \} \subseteq \mathcal{P}P:={P1​,…,PN​}⊆P.
  • We'll let Pj=QjnP_j = Q_j^nPj​=Qjn​ for Qj∈QQ_j\in \mathcal{Q}Qj​∈Q.

For any ω∈{0,1}m\omega \in \{ 0,1 \}^mω∈{0,1}m, we define
fω(x)=∑j=1mωjϕj(x),f_\omega(x) = \sum_{j=1}^{m} \omega_j \phi_j(x),fω​(x)=j=1∑m​ωj​ϕj​(x),

where, for a fixed constant h>0h>0h>0, we have m∈[8,1h−1]m \in \left[ 8, \frac{1}{h} - 1 \right]m∈[8,h1​−1] and
ϕj(x)=LhβK(x−jm+1h).\phi_j(x) = Lh^\beta K \left( \frac{x-\frac{j}{m+1}}{h} \right).ϕj​(x)=LhβK(hx−m+1j​​).

Here, for sufficiently small a>0a>0a>0, KKK is defined as
K(x)=aexp⁡(−11−4x2)I{∣x∣<12}.K(x) = a \exp \left( - \frac{1}{1-4x^2} \right) I \left\{ |x| < \frac{1}{2} \right\}.K(x)=aexp(−1−4x21​)I{∣x∣<21​}.

Below we can see a plot of the function KKK.

The quantity aaa is chosen so that fω∈F(β,L)f_\omega \in \mathcal{F}(\beta,L)fω​∈F(β,L) for all ω∈{0,1}m\omega \in \{ 0,1 \}^mω∈{0,1}m

If, for some Ω~⊆{0,1}m\widetilde{\Omega} \subseteq \{ 0,1 \}^mΩ⊆{0,1}m, we applied Fano's method based on {Pω=Qωn:ω∈Ω~}\{ P_\omega = Q_\omega^n: \omega \in \widetilde{\Omega} \}{Pω​=Qωn​:ω∈Ω}, where QωQ_\omegaQω​ is the distribution with regression function fωf_\omegafω​,
inf⁡Tsup⁡pR(T,P)≥min⁡ω≠νd(Pω,Pν)2(1−log⁡(2)+max⁡ω≠νKL(Pω,Pν)log⁡∣Ω~∣).\red{\inf_T \sup_{p} \mathcal{R}(T,P) \geq \frac{\min_{\omega\neq \nu} d(P_\omega, P_\nu)}{2} \left( 1 - \frac{\log(2) + \max_{\omega\neq \nu} \text{KL}(P_\omega, P_\nu)}{\log \left| \widetilde{\Omega} \right|} \right)}.Tinf​psup​R(T,P)≥2minω=ν​d(Pω​,Pν​)​​1−log​Ω​log(2)+maxω=ν​KL(Pω​,Pν​)​​.

From earlier in this chapter
d(Pω,Pν)=12∫[fω(x)−fν(x)]2dx.\blue{d(P_\omega, P_\nu) = \frac{1}{2} \int [f_\omega(x) - f_\nu(x)]^2 dx}.d(Pω​,Pν​)=21​∫[fω​(x)−fν​(x)]2dx.

KL(Pω,Pν)=n2∫[fω(x)−fν(x)]2dx.\blue{\text{KL}(P_\omega, P_\nu) = \frac{n}{2} \int [f_\omega(x) - f_\nu(x)]^2 dx}.KL(Pω​,Pν​)=2n​∫[fω​(x)−fν​(x)]2dx.

Since none of the bump functions overlap, ϕj(x)ϕk(x)=0\phi_j(x) \phi_k(x) = 0ϕj​(x)ϕk​(x)=0 for all j≠kj\neq kj=k, and so
∫[fω(x)−fν(x)]2dx=∫01[∑j=1m(ωj−νj)ϕj(x)]2dx=∑j=1m(ωj−νj)∫ϕj(x)2dx=∑j=1m(ωj−νj)2L2h2β+1∫K(u)2du⏟c2=c2L2h2β+1H(ω,ν),\begin{align*} \int [f_\omega(x) - f_\nu(x)]^2 dx &= \int_{0}^{1} \left[ \sum_{j=1}^{m} (\omega_j - \nu_j) \phi_j(x) \right]^2 dx \\ &= \sum_{j=1}^{m} (\omega_j - \nu_j) \int \phi_j(x)^2 dx \\ &= \sum_{j=1}^{m} (\omega_j - \nu_j)^2 L^2 h^{2\beta+1} \underbrace{\int K(u)^2 du}_{c_2} \tag{u-substitution} \\ &= c_2 L^2 h^{2\beta+1} H(\omega, \nu), \end{align*}∫[fω​(x)−fν​(x)]2dx​=∫01​[j=1∑m​(ωj​−νj​)ϕj​(x)]2dx=j=1∑m​(ωj​−νj​)∫ϕj​(x)2dx=j=1∑m​(ωj​−νj​)2L2h2β+1c2​∫K(u)2du​​=c2​L2h2β+1H(ω,ν),​(u-substitution)​

where H(ω,ν):=∑j=1n(ωj−νj)2H(\omega,\nu) := \sum_{j=1}^{n} (\omega_j - \nu_j)^2H(ω,ν):=∑j=1n​(ωj​−νj​)2 denotes the Hamming distance between ω\omegaω and ν\nuν.

Plugging the above into the preceding two colored expressions and c3:=c2L22c_3 := \frac{c_2 L^2}{2}c3​:=2c2​L2​, we find that
d(Pω,Pν)=c3h2β+1H(ω,ν)d(P_\omega, P_\nu) = c_3 h^{2\beta+1} H(\omega,\nu)d(Pω​,Pν​)=c3​h2β+1H(ω,ν)

and

Also, since H(ω,ν)≤mH(\omega, \nu) \leq mH(ω,ν)≤m, we have that
max⁡ω≠νKL(Pω,Pν)≤c3nh2β+1m.\blue{\max_{\omega\neq \nu} \text{KL}(P_\omega, P_\nu) \leq c_3 n h^{2\beta+1} m}.ω=νmax​KL(Pω​,Pν​)≤c3​nh2β+1m.

Plugging the above into Fano’s lower bound\red{\text{Fano's lower bound}}Fano’s lower bound,
inf⁡Tsup⁡pR(T,P)≥c3h2β+12min⁡ω≠νH(ω,ν)⋅[1−log⁡(2)+c3nh2β+1mlog⁡∣Ω~∣].\inf_T \sup_p R(T,P) \geq \frac{c_3 h^{2\beta+1}}{2} \min_{\omega\neq \nu} H(\omega,\nu) \cdot \left[ 1 - \frac{\log(2) + c_3 n h^{2\beta+1} m}{ \log \left| \widetilde{\Omega} \right|} \right].Tinf​psup​R(T,P)≥2c3​h2β+1​ω=νmin​H(ω,ν)⋅​1−log​Ω​log(2)+c3​nh2β+1m​​.

In what follows, we'll consider two choices of Ω~⊆{0,1}m\widetilde{\Omega} \subseteq \{ 0,1 \}^mΩ⊆{0,1}m.

  • Choice 1: Ω~={0,1}m\widetilde{\Omega} = \{ 0,1 \}^mΩ={0,1}m. In this case,
    min⁡ω≠νH(ω,ν)=1,log⁡∣Ω~∣=mlog⁡(2)\begin{align*} \min_{\omega\neq\nu} H(\omega, \nu) &= 1, \\ \log \left| \widetilde{\Omega} \right| &= m\log(2) \end{align*}ω=νmin​H(ω,ν)log​Ω​​=1,=mlog(2)​

    Plugging this into the above, we have
    inf⁡Tsup⁡pR(T,P)≥c3h2β+12(1−log⁡(2)+c3nh2β+1mmlog⁡(2)).\begin{align*} \inf_T \sup_p R(T,P) \geq \frac{c_3 h^{2\beta+1}}{2} \left( 1 - \frac{\log(2) + c_3 nh^{2\beta+1} m}{m\log(2)} \right). \end{align*}Tinf​psup​R(T,P)≥2c3​h2β+1​(1−mlog(2)log(2)+c3​nh2β+1m​).​

    I claim the above can't give a lower bound sharper (larger) than O(1n)O(\tfrac{1}{n})O(n1​). To see why, note the following:

    1. If nh2β+1nh^{2\beta+1}nh2β+1 is larger, then the LB is negative.

      • So, want h=O(n−12β+1)h=O\left( n^{-\frac{1}{2\beta+1}} \right)h=O(n−2β+11​).

    2. In the best case, the RHS is no more than c3h2β+1/2c_3 h^{2\beta+1}/2c3​h2β+1/2.

    Combining these two observations, the lower bound is never going to be sharper than O(1n)O(\tfrac{1}{n})O(n1​).

From what you saw in STAT 581, you might expect this LB be to loose. In particular, consider the parametric problem where fQ:F~:={x↦βx:β∈[0,L]}f_Q: \widetilde{\mathcal{F}} := \left\{ x \mapsto \beta x: \beta\in [0,L] \right\}fQ​:F:={x↦βx:β∈[0,L]}

From last quarter, we know that the MLE satisfies
n(β−β^)→dN(0,σ2)\sqrt{n} (\hat{\beta - \beta}) \stackrel{d}{\to} N(0,\sigma^2)n​(β−β^​)→dN(0,σ2)

Hence,
(β^−β)2=Op(1n).(\hat{\beta} - \beta)^2 = O_p(\tfrac{1}{n}).(β^​−β)2=Op​(n1​).

Hence, it's reasonable to expect that
EQn[∫(β^x−βx)2dx]=O(1n).E_{Q^n} \left[ \int (\hat{\beta}_x - \beta_x)^2 dx \right] = O(\tfrac{1}{n}).EQn​[∫(β^​x​−βx​)2dx]=O(n1​).


  • Choice 2. Idea: find an Ω~⊆{0,1}m\widetilde{\Omega} \subseteq \{ 0,1 \}^mΩ⊆{0,1}m such that log⁡∣Ω~∣\log \left| \widetilde{\Omega} \right|log​Ω​ and min⁡ω≠νH(ω,ν)\min_{\omega\neq \nu} H(\omega,\nu)minω=ν​H(ω,ν) are both large.

Varshamov-Gilbert Lemma. If m≥0m\geq 0m≥0, then there exists a subset Ω~⊆{0,1}m\widetilde{\Omega} \subseteq \{ 0,1 \}^mΩ⊆{0,1}m such that ∣Ω~∣≥2m/8\left| \widetilde{\Omega} \right| \geq 2^{m/8}​Ω​≥2m/8 and min⁡ω≠νH(ω,ν)≥m8\min_{\omega\neq\nu} H(\omega, \nu) \geq \tfrac{m}{8}minω=ν​H(ω,ν)≥8m​.


Choosing Ω~\widetilde{\Omega}Ω as in the lemma, our lower bound\boxed{\red{\text{lower bound}}}lower bound​
inf⁡Tsup⁡pR(T,P)≥c3h2β+1m16(1−log⁡(2)+8c3nh2β+1mlog⁡(2)/8)=c3h2β+1m16(1−8m−8c3nh2β+1log⁡(2)).\begin{align*} \inf_T \sup_p R(T,P) &\geq \frac{c_3 h^{2\beta+1} m}{16} \left( 1 - \frac{\log(2) + 8c_3 nh^{2\beta+1}}{m\log(2) / 8} \right) \\ &= \frac{c_3 h^{2\beta+1} m}{16} \left( 1 - \frac{8}{m} - \frac{8c_3 nh^{2\beta+1}}{\log(2)} \right). \end{align*}Tinf​psup​R(T,P)​≥16c3​h2β+1m​(1−mlog(2)/8log(2)+8c3​nh2β+1​)=16c3​h2β+1m​(1−m8​−log(2)8c3​nh2β+1​).​

We'll choose mmm as large as possible (i.e., ⌊mL1h−1⌋\lfloor{m L \frac{1}{h} - 1\rfloor}⌊mLh1​−1⌋). Approximating this as m≈1hm\approx \frac{1}{h}m≈h1​, we find
LB≈c3h2β16(1−8h−8c3nh2β+1log⁡(2)).(★)LB \approx \frac{c_3 h^{2\beta}}{16} \left( 1 - 8h - \frac{8 c_3 nh^{2\beta + 1}}{\log(2)} \right) \tag{$\bigstar$}.LB≈16c3​h2β​(1−8h−log(2)8c3​nh2β+1​).(★)

For (★)(\bigstar)(★) to be nonnegative, we need h≤c4n−12β+1h\leq c_4 n^{-\frac{1}{2\beta+1}}h≤c4​n−2β+11​ for an appropriately specified c4c_4c4​. Letting h=c42n−12β+1h = \frac{c_4}{2} n^{- \frac{1}{2\beta+1}}h=2c4​​n−2β+11​, we find that there's a c5>0c_5>0c5​>0 such that
inf⁡Tsup⁡pR(T,P)≥c5n−2β2β+1.\inf_T \sup_p R(T,P) \geq c_5 n^{-\frac{2\beta}{2\beta+1}}.Tinf​psup​R(T,P)≥c5​n−2β+12β​.

For example, if β=2\beta=2β=2, then we've derived an n−4/5n^{-4/5}n−4/5-rate lower bound on the minimax risk. [Note: This is tight (in terms of rates)!]

This means n−4/5n^{-4/5}n−4/5 is the sharpest we can get and there is no lower bound that is asymptotically larger.

Setting:

  • Observe X1,X2,…,Xn∼iidQX_1,X_2,\dots,X_n \stackrel{iid}{\sim} QX1​,X2​,…,Xn​∼iidQ
    • Let F(x):=Q{X≤x}F(x) := Q\{ X\leq x \}F(x):=Q{X≤x} be the cumulative density function
    • Let f(x)f(x)f(x) denote the probability density function
      • Note that we are assuming that we are always working with a continuous distribution

Our goal: Estimate fff at a point x0x_0x0​.

  • Given that f(x0)=ddxF(x)∣x=x0f(x_0) = \left. \frac{d}{dx} F(x) \right|_{x=x_0}f(x0​)=dxd​F(x)​x=x0​​, we might consider using a plugin estimator
    f^(x0)=ddxF^(x0).(1)\hat{f}(x_0) = \frac{d}{dx} \hat{F}(x_0). \tag{1}f^​(x0​)=dxd​F^(x0​).(1)

    One way to estimate FFF is via the empirical CDF
    F^(x0):=1n∑i=1nI{Xi≤x0}.\hat{F}(x_0) := \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} I \left\{ X_i \leq x_0 \right\}.F^(x0​):=n1​i=1∑n​I{Xi​≤x0​}.

  • We know that F^\hat{F}F^ is a "good" estimator of FFF.

    • e.g., n[F^(x0)−F(x0)]→dN(0,σ2)\sqrt{n} \left[ \hat{F}(x_0) - F(x_0) \right] \stackrel{d}{\to} N(0,\sigma^2)n​[F^(x0​)−F(x0​)]→dN(0,σ2).

  • But: estimating f(x0)f(x_0)f(x0​) via (1)(1)(1) turns out to be a very bad idea. To see why, refer to the image below.


  • Another possible estimator uses that
    f(x0)=lim⁡h→0F(x0+h)−F(x0−h)2h,f(x_0) = \lim_{h\to 0} \frac{F(x_0 + h) - F(x_0 - h)}{2h},f(x0​)=h→0lim​2hF(x0​+h)−F(x0​−h)​,

    and so, for h>0h>0h>0 small,
    f(x0)≈F(x0+h)−F(x0−h)2h.f(x_0) \approx \frac{F(x_0+h) - F(x_0-h)}{2h}.f(x0​)≈2hF(x0​+h)−F(x0​−h)​.

    This suggest the estimator
    f^(x0)=F^(x0+h)−F^(x0−h)2h=12nh∑i=1nI{x0−h<Xi≤x0+h}=(a.s.)1nh∑i=1n12 I{∣Xi−x0∣h≤1}.\begin{align*} \hat{f}(x_0) &= \frac{\hat{F}(x_0+h) - \hat{F}(x_0-h)}{2h} \\ &= \frac{1}{2nh} \sum_{i=1}^{n} I \{ x_0 - h < X_i \leq x_0 + h \} \\ &\stackrel{(a.s.)}{=} \frac{1}{nh} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{2} \, I \left\{ \frac{|X_i - x_0 | }{h} \leq 1 \right\}. \end{align*}f^​(x0​)​=2hF^(x0​+h)−F^(x0​−h)​=2nh1​i=1∑n​I{x0​−h<Xi​≤x0​+h}=(a.s.)nh1​i=1∑n​21​I{h∣Xi​−x0​∣​≤1}.​

    Below is an example of what a simple kernel estimator might look like in this case.



    Note: This estimate of fff is not smooth because it is not continuous or differentiable.

Question: Can we define a smoother estimate of fff?

Answer: Yes!

  • Let K:R→RK: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}K:R→R be a kernel, that is, a function satisfying ∫K(u)du=1\int K(u) du = 1∫K(u)du=1.

Definition. An sths^{th}sth order kernel KKK satisfies

  • ∫urK(u)du=0\int u^r K(u) du = 0∫urK(u)du=0 for r=1,2,…,s−1r=1,2,\dots,s-1r=1,2,…,s−1;
  • ∣∫usK(u)du<∞|\int u^s K(u) du < \infty∣∫usK(u)du<∞.
    • This is just saying that ∫K(u)udu=0\int K(u) u du = 0∫K(u)udu=0

Note: We call hhh the bandwidth of the kernel density estimator.

  • If KKK is symmetric about zero [K(u)=K(−u)K(u) = K(-u)K(u)=K(−u)] then KKK is necessarily at least a second-order kernel.

  • Using higher-order kernels (s>2s>2s>2) can lead to estimators with lower bias.


General form of the Kernel Density Estimator (KDE)

For a bandwidth h>0h>0h>0:
f^h(x0)=1n∑i=1n1hK(Xi−x0h)=1n∑i=1nKh(Xi−x0)\begin{align*} \hat{f}_h(x_0) &= \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{h} K \left( \frac{X_i - x_0}{h} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} K_h(X_i-x_0) \end{align*}f^​h​(x0​)​=n1​i=1∑n​h1​K(hXi​−x0​​)=n1​i=1∑n​Kh​(Xi​−x0​)​

where Kh(u)=1hK(uh)K_h(u) = \frac{1}{h} K \left( \frac{u}{h} \right)Kh​(u)=h1​K(hu​).

Examples of kernels:

  1. Uniform kernel:
    K(u)=12I{∣u∣≤1}.(★)K(u) = \frac{1}{2} I \{ |u|\leq 1 \}. \tag{$\blue{\bigstar}$}K(u)=21​I{∣u∣≤1}.(★)

  2. Epanechnikov kernel:
    K(u)=34(1−u2)I{∣u∣≤1}K(u) = \frac{3}{4} (1 - u^2) I \{ |u| \leq 1 \}K(u)=43​(1−u2)I{∣u∣≤1}

  3. Gaussian kernel:
    K(u)=12πexp⁡[−u22]K(u) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp \left[ -\frac{u^2}{2} \right]K(u)=2π​1​exp[−2u2​]

Note: All of these kernels are second-order.


Studying f^h(x0)\hat{f}_h(x_0)f^​h​(x0​) as an estimator of f(x0)f(x_0)f(x0​)

We'll quantify performance in terms of MSE:
E[{f^h(x0)−f(x0)}2]={E[f^h(x0)]−f(x0)}2⏟bias2+var(f^h(x0))⏟varianceE \left[ \left\{ \hat{f}_h(x_0) - f(x_0) \right\}^2 \right] = \underbrace{\red{ \left\{ E[\hat{f}_h(x_0)] - f(x_0) \right\}^2}}_{\text{bias}^2} + \underbrace{\blue{var(\hat{f}_h(x_0))}}_{\text{variance}}E[{f^​h​(x0​)−f(x0​)}2]=bias2{E[f^​h​(x0​)]−f(x0​)}2​​+variancevar(f^​h​(x0​))​​

We'll suppose that fff belong to a (β,L)(\beta,L)(β,L) Hölder class with β=2\beta=2β=2 and L>0L>0L>0.

Recall: Saying that fff is (2,L)(2,L)(2,L) Hölder means that
∣f′(x1)−f′(x2)∣≤L∣x1−x2∣∀x1,x2.\left| f'(x_1) - f'(x_2) \right| \leq L |x_1 - x_2| \hspace{2em} \forall x_1, x_2.∣f′(x1​)−f′(x2​)∣≤L∣x1​−x2​∣∀x1​,x2​.

Note: All of the calculations we do today will still go through if fff isn't Hölder, but there exists a neighborhood of x0x_0x0​ such that the restriction of fff to that neighborhood is (2,L)(2,L)(2,L) Hölder.

We'll focus on the case where KKK:

  • is bounded;
  • is nonnegative;
  • is second-order; and
  • has bounded support.

We're going to see that choosing a small bandwidth h>0h>0h>0 yields low bias\red{\text{low bias}}low bias and high variance\blue{\text{high variance}}high variance, and vice versa.


Bias\red{\textbf{Bias}}Bias of the KDE

Recall: The bias is Bias=E[f^h(x0)]−f(x0)\text{Bias} = E[\hat{f}_h(x_0)] - f(x_0)Bias=E[f^​h​(x0​)]−f(x0​) and f(x0)=∫K(u)f(x0)duf(x_0) = \int K(u) f(x_0) duf(x0​)=∫K(u)f(x0​)du (since ∫K(u)du=1\int K(u) du = 1∫K(u)du=1). Thus, we have
E[f^h(x0)]=1nh∑i=1nE[K(Xi−x0h)]=1hE[K(X1−x0h)]=1h∫K(x1−x0h)f(x1)dx1m=∫K(u)f(x0+uh)du.\begin{align*} E\left[ \hat{f}_h(x_0) \right] &= \frac{1}{nh} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E \left[ K \left( \frac{X_i - x_0}{h} \right) \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{h} E \left[ K \left( \frac{X_1 - x_0}{h} \right) \right] \tag{identically distributed} \\ &= \frac{1}{h} \int K \left( \frac{x_1 - x_0}{h} \right) f(x_1) dx_1 \tag{$u = \tfrac{x_1-x_0}{h}$}m \\ &= \int K(u) f(x_0 + uh) du. \end{align*}E[f^​h​(x0​)]​=nh1​i=1∑n​E[K(hXi​−x0​​)]=h1​E[K(hX1​−x0​​)]=h1​∫K(hx1​−x0​​)f(x1​)dx1​m=∫K(u)f(x0​+uh)du.​(identically distributed)(u=hx1​−x0​​)​

Recalling that ∫K(u)du=1\int K(u) du = 1∫K(u)du=1, we have
Bias=∫K(u)[f(x0+uh)−f(x0)]⏟★du.\text{Bias} = \int K(u) \underbrace{[f(x_0+ uh) - f(x_0)]}_{\purple{\bigstar}} du.Bias=∫K(u)★[f(x0​+uh)−f(x0​)]​​du.

By the mean value theorem, there exists x~uh\tilde{x}_{uh}x~uh​ between x0+uhx_0+uhx0​+uh and x0x_0x0​ such that
★=uhf′(x~uh).\purple{\bigstar} = uh f'(\tilde{x}_{uh}).★=uhf′(x~uh​).

Hence,
Bias=∫K(u)uh f′(x~uh)du=∫K(u)uhf′(x0)du⏟hf′(x0)∫K(u)udu=0 b/c K is 2nd-order+∫K(u)uh[f′(x~uh)−f′(x0)]du.\begin{align*} \text{Bias} &= \int K(u) uh \, f'(\tilde{x}_{uh}) du \\ &= \underbrace{\int K(u) uh f'(x_0) du}_{\substack{\purple{h f'(x_0) \int K(u) u du} \\ \purple{=0 \text{ b/c } K \text{ is } 2^{nd} \text{-order}}}} + \int K(u) uh \left[ f'(\tilde{x}_{uh}) - f'(x_0) \right] du. \end{align*}Bias​=∫K(u)uhf′(x~uh​)du=hf′(x0​)∫K(u)udu=0 b/c K is 2nd-order​∫K(u)uhf′(x0​)du​​+∫K(u)uh[f′(x~uh​)−f′(x0​)]du.​

We're leveraging the fact that x~uh\tilde{x}_{uh}x~uh​ is close to x0x_0x0​, as can be seen on the number line below:

Hence,
∣Bias∣=∣∫K(u)uh[f′(x~uh)−f′(x0)]du∣≤h∫K(u)∣u∣∣f′(x~uh)−f′(x0)∣du≤Lh∫K(u)∣u∣∣x~uh−x0∣⏟∣u∣hdu≤Lh∫K(u)u2du⏟:=σk2 (constant).\begin{align*} |\text{Bias}| &= \left| \int K(u) uh [f'(\tilde{x}_{uh}) - f'(x_0)] du \right| \\ &\leq h \int K(u) \vert u| |f'(\tilde{x}_{uh}) - f'(x_0)| du \\ &\leq L h \int K(u) |u| \underbrace{|\tilde{x}_{uh} - x_0 |}_{\orange{|u| h}} du \\ &\leq Lh \underbrace{\int K(u) u^2 du}_{:=\sigma_k^2 \text{ (constant)}}. \end{align*}∣Bias∣​=​∫K(u)uh[f′(x~uh​)−f′(x0​)]du​≤h∫K(u)∣u∣∣f′(x~uh​)−f′(x0​)∣du≤Lh∫K(u)∣u∣∣u∣h∣x~uh​−x0​∣​​du≤Lh:=σk2​ (constant)∫K(u)u2du​​.​

Hence,
Bias2≤Lσk4h4.\red{\boxed{\text{Bias}^2 \leq L \sigma_k^4 h^4}}.Bias2≤Lσk4​h4​.

Variance\blue{\text{Variance}}Variance of the KDE:

var[f^h(x0)]=var[1nh∑i=1nK(Xi−x0h)]=1n2h2∑i=1nvar[K(Xi−x0h)]=1nh2var[K(X1−x0h)]≤1nh2E[K(x1−x0h)2]=1nh2∫K(x1−x0h)2f(x1)dx1=1nh∫K(u)2f(x0+uh)du⏟(★★)u=x1−x0h\begin{align*} var[\hat{f}_h(x_0)] &= var \left[ \frac{1}{nh} \sum_{i=1}^{n} K \left( \frac{X_i - x_0}{h} \right) \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{n^2h^2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} var\left[ K \left( \frac{X_i - x_0}{h} \right) \right] \tag{ind.} \\ &= \frac{1}{nh^2} var \left[ K \left( \frac{X_1 - x_0}{h} \right) \right] \tag{ident.} \\ &\leq \frac{1}{nh^2} E \left[ K\left( \frac{x_1 - x_0}{h} \right)^2 \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{nh^2} \int K \left( \frac{x_1-x_0}{h} \right)^2 f(x_1) dx_1 \\ &= \frac{1}{nh} \underbrace{\int K(u)^2 f(x_0 + uh) du}_{\purple{(\bigstar\bigstar})} \hspace{2em} u= \frac{x_1 - x_0}{h} \tag{2} \end{align*}var[f^​h​(x0​)]​=var[nh1​i=1∑n​K(hXi​−x0​​)]=n2h21​i=1∑n​var[K(hXi​−x0​​)]=nh21​var[K(hX1​−x0​​)]≤nh21​E[K(hx1​−x0​​)2]=nh21​∫K(hx1​−x0​​)2f(x1​)dx1​=nh1​(★★)∫K(u)2f(x0​+uh)du​​u=hx1​−x0​​​(ind.)(ident.)(2)​

We'll study (★★)\purple{(\bigstar\bigstar)}(★★) in what follows. To do this, we'll use the following two facts:

  1. fff is Hölder continuous, and therefore, continuous in general;
  2. KKK has bounded support.

Let k1:=inf⁡{u:K(u)>0}k_1:= \inf\left\{ u: K(u)>0 \right\}k1​:=inf{u:K(u)>0} and k2:=sup⁡{u:K(u)>0}k_2:= \sup \left\{ u: K(u)>0 \right\}k2​:=sup{u:K(u)>0}. We have that
★★=∫[k1,k2]K(u)2f(x0+uh)du≤[sup⁡u∈[k1,k2]f(x0+uh)]∫[k1,k2]K(u)2du.\begin{align*} \purple{\bigstar\bigstar} &= \int_{[k_1,k_2]} K(u)^2 f(x_0 + uh) du \\ &\leq \left[ \sup_{u\in[k_1,k_2]} f(x_0+uh) \right] \int_{[k_1,k_2]} K(u)^2 du. \end{align*}★★​=∫[k1​,k2​]​K(u)2f(x0​+uh)du≤[u∈[k1​,k2​]sup​f(x0​+uh)]∫[k1​,k2​]​K(u)2du.​

If h≤1h\leq 1h≤1, then this shows
≤[sup⁡t∈[k1,k2]f(x0+t)]∫[k1,k2]K(u)2du⏟C~.\begin{align*} &\leq \underbrace{\left[ \sup_{t\in[k_1,k_2]} f(x_0+t) \right] \int_{[k_1,k_2]} K(u)^2 du}_{\orange{\widetilde{C}}}. \end{align*}​≤C[t∈[k1​,k2​]sup​f(x0​+t)]∫[k1​,k2​]​K(u)2du​​.​

Recall that continuous functions are bounded over compact sets. Also remember that we are trying to find a bound that does not depend on hhh. Also note that since KKK is bounded, we know that the above will be a finite constant.

Plugging the above into (2)(2)(2),
var(f^h(x0))≤C~nh.\blue{var(\hat{f}_{h}(x_0)) \leq \frac{\widetilde{C}}{nh}}.var(f^​h​(x0​))≤nhC​.

Generalizations and Conclusions

Conclusion: Plugging in our bounds in Bias2\red{\boxed{\text{Bias}^2}}Bias2​ and var\blue{\boxed{var}}var​, we find that
sup⁡QMSE≤L2σk2h4+C~nh(▲)\purple{\sup_Q} \text{MSE} \leq \red{L^2 \sigma_k^2 h^4} + \blue{\frac{\widetilde{C}}{nh}} \tag{$\purple{\blacktriangle}$}Qsup​MSE≤L2σk2​h4+nhC​(▲)

Note from Alex: The first terms shrinks as hhh becomes small and the second grows. Setting the two terms equal to each other and solving for hhh will provide a note describing how hhh should change with nnn to make the bound as tight as possible. Setting the two terms to each other and solving for hhh is the best way to balance out the two terms.
L2σk4h4=C~nh  ⟹  h=Cn−1/5L^2 \sigma_k^4 h^4 = \frac{\widetilde{C}}{nh} \implies h = Cn^{-1/5}L2σk4​h4=nhC​⟹h=Cn−1/5

for some CCC. Plugging this into our bound on the MSE, we find that choosing the bandwidth yields
MSE=O(n−4/5).MSE = O(n^{-4/5}).MSE=O(n−4/5).

Note to self: We are studying the bias-variance tradeoff, so increasing the variance will increase the bias, and vice-versa. Our goal is to choose an hhh that balances out these two terms so neither of them are too large. Also note that removing the supremum from (▲)(\purple{\blacktriangle})(▲) makes it possible for the upper bound to be loose under certain conditions.


Generalizations

  1. 1-dimensional settings with different levels of smoothness:

      If fff belong to a (β,L)(\beta,L)(β,L) Hölder class, then similar arguments show that when we choose an appropriate hhh
      MSE=O(n−2β2β+1)\text{MSE} = O\left( n^{-\frac{2\beta}{2\beta+1}} \right)MSE=O(n−2β+12β​)

      if a kernel of sufficiently high order is user

      Note: Large values of β\betaβ   ⟹  \implies⟹ more smoothness.

  2. ddd-dimensional settings:

      Suppose XXX is ddd-dimensional. A KDE in this case takes the form
      f^h(x0)=1nhd∑i=1n∏j=1dK(Xi,j−x0,jh).\hat{f}_h(x_0) = \frac{1}{nh^d} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \prod_{j=1}^{d} K \left( \frac{X_{i,j} - x_{0,j}}{h} \right).f^​h​(x0​)=nhd1​i=1∑n​j=1∏d​K(hXi,j​−x0,j​​).

      If fff is β-times differentiable\blue{\beta\text{-times differentiable}}β-times differentiable and all partial derivatives up to order β\betaβ are bounded, then for proper choice of bandwidth hhh, we have
      MSE=O(n−2β2β+d)\text{MSE} = O\left( n^{-\frac{2\blue{\beta}}{2\blue{\beta}+\red{d}}} \right)MSE=O(n−2β+d2β​)

      To see this more clearly, reference the below table.

      dimension (ddd) MSE upper bound
      1 n−0.80n^{-0.80}n−0.80
      2 n−0.67n^{-0.67}n−0.67
      4 n−0.50n^{-0.50}n−0.50
      10 n−0.29n^{-0.29}n−0.29

      One way of thinking about the exponent: If MSE=n−α\text{MSE} = n^{-\alpha}MSE=n−α, then, when nnn is large, to halve your MSE, you need to collect to 21/α2^{1/\alpha}21/α as many observations.


Chapter 3. Concentration Inequality.

Chapter 3 Table of Contents

  • Bounds on Moments
  • Sub-Gaussian Random Variables
    • Alternative Characterizations of Sub-Gaussianity
  • Sub-Exponential Random Variables
    • An alternative characterization of sub-exponential random variables
  • Bounded Differences Inequality

Other Sections: Chapter 1, Chapter 2, Chapter 4 - Part 1, Chapter 4 - Part 2


References: Chapter 2 of the Wainwright textbook

Note: In this chapter, it is often not required that the data be identically distributed, and independence is typically all we need.

Objection/Motivation: Suppose X1,X2,…,XnX_1,X_2,\dots,X_nX1​,X2​,…,Xn​ are independent random variables.

  • In many cases, it will be useful to find bounds on some function fff of X1,…,XnX_1,\dots,X_nX1​,…,Xn​.

    • That is, we want to bound
      P{f(X1,…,Xn)≥t}for some t>0.(1)P \{ f(X_1,\dots,X_n) \geq t \} \hspace{2em} \text{for some } t>0. \tag{1}P{f(X1​,…,Xn​)≥t}for some t>0.(1)

  • For the first part of this chapter, we'll focus on fff of the form
    f:(x1,…,xn)⏟x1n↦1n∑i=1nxif: \underbrace{(x_1,\dots,x_n)}_{\blue{x_1^n}} \mapsto \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_if:x1n​(x1​,…,xn​)​​↦n1​i=1∑n​xi​

    or
    f:x1n↦∣1n∑i=1nxi−E[1n∑i=1nXi]∣.f: x_1^n \mapsto \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i - E \left[ \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} X_i \right] \right|.f:x1n​↦​n1​i=1∑n​xi​−E[n1​i=1∑n​Xi​]​.

  • We could consider upper bounding (1)(1)(1) using asymptotics.

    For example, if X1,…,XnX_1,\dots,X_nX1​,…,Xn​ are not just independent, but also identically distributed, we have μ:=E[X]\mu := E[X]μ:=E[X] and σ2=var(X)\sigma^2 = var(X)σ2=var(X), then the CLT says that
    P{Xˉn≥μ+tσn}⟶n→∞1−Φ(t),P \left\{ \bar{X}_n \geq \mu + \frac{t\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \right\} \stackrel{n\to\infty}{\longrightarrow} 1 - \Phi(t),P{Xˉn​≥μ+n​tσ​}⟶n→∞​1−Φ(t),

    where Φ\PhiΦ represents the CDF of the standard normal distribution.

    But: we usually only have a finite sample size, and so these guarantees are only approximate.

Question: What can we say in finite samples? For example, can we say that
P{Xˉn≥μ+t}≤∘P \left\{ \bar{X}_n \geq \mu + t \right\} \leq \circP{Xˉn​≥μ+t}≤∘

During this chapter, we'll obtain bounds on (1)(1)(1) using:

  1. Bounds on moments: Markov, Chebyshev.

  2. Bounds on the MGF:

    • Chernoff bound,
    • Hoeffding,
    • sub-Gaussian random variables,
    • sub-exponential random variables, and
    • Bernstein's inequality.

  3. Martingale arguments: Azuma-Hoeffding bound, bounded differences inequality.


Bounds on Moments

Theorem (Markov). If (1) X≥0X\geq 0X≥0, (2) E[X]<∞E[X]<\inftyE[X]<∞, and (3) t>0t>0t>0, then
P{X≥t}≤E[X]t.P \left\{ X\geq t \right\} \leq \frac{E[X]}{t}.P{X≥t}≤tE[X]​.


Proof. For any t>0t>0t>0,
P{X≥t}=∫t∞1dP(x)≤∫t∞xtdP(x)(1≤xt whenever t≤x)≤∫0∞xtdP(x)=E[X]t.\begin{align*} P \left\{ X\geq t \right\} &= \int_t^\infty \purple{1} dP(x) \\ &\leq \int_t^\infty \purple{\frac{x}{t}} dP(x) \hspace{2em} \purple{ \left( 1 \leq \frac{x}{t} \text{ whenever } t\leq x \right) } \\ &\leq \int_0^\infty \frac{x}{t} dP(x) \\ &= \frac{E[X]}{t}. \end{align*}P{X≥t}​=∫t∞​1dP(x)≤∫t∞​tx​dP(x)(1≤tx​ whenever t≤x)≤∫0∞​tx​dP(x)=tE[X]​.​


Note: Note all of our concentration inequalities use Markov's inequality as a building block.

Theorem. Suppose that E∣X∣<∞E|X|<\inftyE∣X∣<∞, where h:[0,∞)→[0,∞)h: [0,\infty) \to [0,\infty)h:[0,∞)→[0,∞), is a nondecreasing function for which h(t)>0h(t)>0h(t)>0 for all t>0t>0t>0, and E[h(∣X−E[X]∣)]<∞E[h(|X- E[X]|)] < \inftyE[h(∣X−E[X]∣)]<∞. For all t>0t>0t>0,
P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}≤E[h(∣X−E[X]∣)]h(t).P \left\{ |X- E[X]| \geq t \right\} \leq \frac{E[h(|X-E[X]|)]}{h(t)}.P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}≤h(t)E[h(∣X−E[X]∣)]​.


Proof. Because hhh is nondecreasing,
{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}⊆{h(∣X−E[X]∣)≥h(t)}.\{ |X-E[X]| \geq t \} \subseteq \left\{ h(|X-E[X]|) \geq h(t) \right\}.{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}⊆{h(∣X−E[X]∣)≥h(t)}.

Hence,
P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}≤P{h(∣X−E[X]∣)≥h(t)}≤E[h(∣X−E[X]∣)]h(t).(by Markov)\begin{align*} P \left\{ |X- E[X]| \geq t \right\} &\leq P \left\{ h(|X-E[X]|) \geq h(t) \right\} \\ &\leq \frac{E[h(|X-E[X]|)]}{h(t)}. \hspace{4em} \purple{\text{(by Markov)}} \end{align*}P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}​≤P{h(∣X−E[X]∣)≥h(t)}≤h(t)E[h(∣X−E[X]∣)]​.(by Markov)​


Example: Chebyshev.
Let h(t)=t2h(t) = t^2h(t)=t2. Then,
P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}≤E[∣X−E[X]∣2]t2=var(X)t2.P \left\{ |X-E[X]| \geq t \right\} \leq \frac{E[|X-E[X]|^2]}{t^2} = \frac{var(X)}{t^2}.P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}≤t2E[∣X−E[X]∣2]​=t2var(X)​.

In fact, we can similarly take h(t)=tkh(t) = t^kh(t)=tk for any k>0k>0k>0 to find
P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}≤E[∣X−E[X]∣k]tk.P \left\{ |X-E[X]| \geq t \right\} \leq \frac{E[|X-E[X]|^k]}{t^k}.P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}≤tkE[∣X−E[X]∣k]​.


Remark. Suppose ℓ<k\ell<kℓ<k and both E[∣X−E[X]∣ℓ]E[|X-E[X]|^\ell]E[∣X−E[X]∣ℓ] and E[∣X−E[X]∣k]E[|X-E[X]|^k]E[∣X−E[X]∣k] are both finite. For large ttt, the bound based on kkk will be much sharper.

  • Why? 1tk\frac{1}{t^k}tk1​ decays much faster than 1tℓ\frac{1}{t^\ell}tℓ1​ as ttt grows.

This is somewhat intuitive: having E[∣X−E[X]∣k]<∞E[|X-E[X]|^k] <\inftyE[∣X−E[X]∣k]<∞ is a stronger condition that having E[∣X−E[X]∣ℓ]E[|X-E[X]|^\ell]E[∣X−E[X]∣ℓ].


Question: Can we get even sharper tail inequalities than the one above if we assume even more about XXX?

Answer: Yes! Provided XXX has a moment-generating function.

Theorem (Chernoff). Suppose that XXX has a MGF in a neighborhood of zero, meaning that there exists b>0b>0b>0 such that
MX(λ):=E[exp⁡{λX}]<∞M_X(\lambda) := E \left[ \exp \{ \lambda X \} \right] < \inftyMX​(λ):=E[exp{λX}]<∞

for all ∣λ∣≤b|\lambda| \leq b∣λ∣≤b. Then, for t>0t>0t>0 and λ∈(0,b]\lambda \in (0,b]λ∈(0,b],
P{X−E[X]≥t}=P{eλ(X−E[X])≥eλt}≤E[eλ(X−E[X])]eλt=:MX−μ(λ)eλt\begin{align*} P \left\{ X - E[X] \geq t \right\} &= P \left\{ e^{\lambda (X-E[X])} \geq e^{\lambda t} \right\} \\ &\leq \frac{E[e^{\lambda(X-E[X])}]}{e^{\lambda t}} \\ &=: \frac{M_{X-\mu}(\lambda)}{e^{\lambda t}} \end{align*}P{X−E[X]≥t}​=P{eλ(X−E[X])≥eλt}≤eλtE[eλ(X−E[X])]​=:eλtMX−μ​(λ)​​


where μ=E[X]\mu = E[X]μ=E[X]. Hence,
P{X−E[X]≥t}≤inf⁡λ>0MX−μ(λ)eλt.P \{ X-E[X] \geq t \} \leq \inf_{\lambda>0} \frac{M_{X-\mu}(\lambda)}{e^{\lambda t}}.P{X−E[X]≥t}≤λ>0inf​eλtMX−μ​(λ)​.

Equivalently,
log⁡P{X−E[X]≥t}≤−sup⁡λ>0{λt−log⁡Mx−μ(λ)⏟“cumulant generatingfunction"}\orange{\boxed{\log P \{ X- E[X] \geq t \} \leq -\sup_{\lambda>0} \left\{ \lambda t - \underbrace{\log M_{x-\mu}(\lambda)}_{\substack{\blue{\text{``cumulant generating}} \\ \blue{\text{function"}}}} \right\}}}logP{X−E[X]≥t}≤−λ>0sup​⎩⎨⎧​λt−“cumulant generatingfunction"​logMx−μ​(λ)​​⎭⎬⎫​​

Remark: Apply Chernoff twice, one to the random variable XXX and once to −X-X−X, we see that
P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}≤P{X−E[X]≥t}+P{X−E[X]≥−t}.\begin{align*} P \left\{ |X-E[X]| \geq t \right\} \leq P \left\{ X - E[X] \geq t \right\} + P \left\{ X-E[X] \geq -t \right\}. \end{align*}P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}≤P{X−E[X]≥t}+P{X−E[X]≥−t}.​

We can use Chernoff to bound each of the two tail probabilities on the right.

Example: Gaussian.

Suppose X∼N(μ,σ2)X\sim N(\mu,\sigma^2)X∼N(μ,σ2). In this case,
MX−μ(λ)=exp⁡{λ2σ22},M_{X-\mu}(\lambda) = \exp \left\{ \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2} \right\},MX−μ​(λ)=exp{2λ2σ2​},

as shown on slide 14 of the lecture notes.

Plugging the form of MX−μ(λ)M_{X-\mu}(\lambda)MX−μ​(λ) info Chernoff\orange{\boxed{\text{Chernoff}}}Chernoff​, we find that
log⁡P{X−μ≥t}≤−sup⁡λ>0{λt−log⁡MX−μ(λ)}=−sup⁡λ>0{λt−λ2σ22}.\begin{align*} \log P \left\{ X- \mu \geq t \right\} &\leq - \sup_{\lambda>0} \left\{ \lambda t - \log M_{X-\mu} (\lambda) \right\} \\ &= - \sup_{\lambda>0} \left\{ \lambda t - \frac{\lambda^2\sigma^2}{2} \right\}. \end{align*}logP{X−μ≥t}​≤−λ>0sup​{λt−logMX−μ​(λ)}=−λ>0sup​{λt−2λ2σ2​}.​

Solving for the λ∗\lambda^*λ∗ that maximizes the above, we find that λ∗=tσ2\lambda^* = \frac{t}{\sigma^2}λ∗=σ2t​. Hence,
log⁡P{X−μ≥t}≤t−2σ2  ⟹  log⁡P{X−μ≥t}≤exp⁡{−t22σ2}.\begin{align*} \log P &\left\{ X- \mu \geq t \right\} \leq \frac{t}{-2\sigma^2} \\ &\implies \log P \left\{ X- \mu \geq t \right\} \leq \exp \left\{ - \frac{t^2}{2\sigma^2} \right\}. \end{align*}logP​{X−μ≥t}≤−2σ2t​⟹logP{X−μ≥t}≤exp{−2σ2t2​}.​

Note that UB(t)UB(t)UB(t) represents the upper bound as a function of ttt.


Sub-Gaussian Random Variables

Definition. A random variable XXX is called sub-Gaussian (sub-G)\blue{\text{sub-Gaussian (sub-G)}}sub-Gaussian (sub-G) with parameter σ2\sigma^2σ2 if
log⁡MX−μ(λ)≤λ2σ22for all λ∈R.\log M_{X-\mu}(\lambda) \leq \frac{\lambda^2\sigma^2}{2} \hspace{2em} \text{for all } \lambda \in\mathbb{R}.logMX−μ​(λ)≤2λ2σ2​for all λ∈R.


The right side of the inequality in the definition is the cumulant generating function of the distribution.

Note: A N(μ,σ2)N(\mu,\sigma^2)N(μ,σ2) random variable is sub-Gaussian with parameter σ2\sigma^2σ2.


By Chernoff, a sub-Gaussian random variable XXX with parameter σ2\sigma^2σ2 satisfies
P{X−E[X]≥t}≤exp⁡{−t22σ2}.\blue{\boxed{P\left\{ X - E[X] \geq t \right\} \leq \exp \left\{ - \frac{t^2}{2\sigma^2} \right\}.}}P{X−E[X]≥t}≤exp{−2σ2t2​}.​

This is the same bound as we derived for a N(μ,σ2)N(\mu,\sigma^2)N(μ,σ2) random variable!

Alternative Characterizations of Sub-Gaussianity

Note: this can be found in Wainwright, Chapter 2.

A random variable XXX is sub-Gaussian if and only if there exist c>0\blue{c>0}c>0 and s>0\orange{s>0}s>0 such that, for all t>0t>0t>0,
P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}≤cP{∣sZ∣≥t},P \left\{ |X-E[X]| \geq t \right\} \leq \blue{c} P \left\{ |\orange{s} Z| \geq t \right\},P{∣X−E[X]∣≥t}≤cP{∣sZ∣≥t},

where Z∼N(0,1)Z\sim N(0,1)Z∼N(0,1).

Remark. s\orange{s}s is not necessarily equal to σ\sigmaσ.

Observe the below plot:

The probability is the area of the curve in the shaded tails.

The dotted line represents a Gaussian with mean zero where, if we shaded under it, the shaded area under the Gaussian density will always be larger.

Counterexample: An Exp(1)\text{Exp}(1)Exp(1) random variable is not sub-Gaussian. Why?
P{X≥t}=exp⁡(−t)P \left\{ X \geq t \right\} = \exp(-t)P{X≥t}=exp(−t)

The decay behavior is too solve, so we will never find c\blue{c}c and s\orange{s}s such that the above is true. Sub-Gaussianity regards tail decay.

Theorem (Hoeffding). If XXX is a random variable with support [a,b][a,b][a,b] (∣a∣,∣b∣<∞|a|, |b| <\infty∣a∣,∣b∣<∞), then XXX is sub-Gaussian with parameter σ2=(b−a)24\sigma^2 = \frac{(b-a)^2}{4}σ2=4(b−a)2​.


Proof. Without loss of generality, suppose that E[X]=0E[X] = 0E[X]=0. Let f(λ)=log⁡MX−μ(λ)f(\lambda) = \log M_{X-\mu}(\lambda)f(λ)=logMX−μ​(λ). Notings that
f′(0)=E[X]E{exp⁡[(X−μ)⋅0]}=E[X]=0,f'(0) = \frac{E[X]}{E \left\{ \exp [(X-\mu)\cdot 0] \right\}} = E[X] = 0,f′(0)=E{exp[(X−μ)⋅0]}E[X]​=E[X]=0,

we have that
f(λ)=∫0∞f′(r)dr⏟=f(λ)−f(0)=f(λ)=∫0λ∫0rf′′(s)ds⏟f′(r)−f′(0)=f′(r) dr.(1)f(\lambda) = \underbrace{\int_0^\infty f'(r) dr}_{\purple{= f(\lambda) - f(0) = f(\lambda)}} = \int_{0}^{\lambda} \underbrace{\int_0^{r} f''(s) ds}_{\purple{f'(r) - f'(0) = f'(r)}} \, dr. \tag*{\textcolor{blue}{(1)}}f(λ)==f(λ)−f(0)=f(λ)∫0∞​f′(r)dr​​=∫0λ​f′(r)−f′(0)=f′(r)∫0r​f′′(s)ds​​dr.(1)

Hence, to bound fff, it's enough to bound f′′f''f′′. Note that
f′(λ)=E[XeλX]E[eλX],f′′(λ)=E[X2eλX]E[eλX]−(E[XeλX]E[eλX])2.\begin{align*} f'(\lambda) &= \frac{E[Xe^{\lambda X}]}{E[e^{\lambda X}]}, \\ f''(\lambda) &= \frac{E[X^2 e^{\lambda X}]}{E[e^{\lambda X}]} - \left( \frac{E[Xe^{\lambda X}]}{E[e^{\lambda X}]} \right)^2. \end{align*}f′(λ)f′′(λ)​=E[eλX]E[XeλX]​,=E[eλX]E[X2eλX]​−(E[eλX]E[XeλX]​)2.​

Note that f′′(λ)f''(\lambda)f′′(λ) is the variance of a RV ZλZ\lambdaZλ with density
x↦eλxE[eλx]p(x).x \mapsto \frac{e^{\lambda x}}{E[e^{\lambda x}]} p(x).x↦E[eλx]eλx​p(x).

Hence,
f′′(λ)=var(Zλ)=var(Zλ−a+b2)≤E[{Zλ−a+b2}2]≤(b−a)24.\begin{align*} f''(\lambda) &= var(Z_\lambda) \\ &= var \left( Z_\lambda - \frac{a+b}{2} \right) \\ &\leq E \left[ \left\{ Z_\lambda - \frac{a+b}{2} \right\}^2 \right] \\ &\leq \frac{(b-a)^2}{4}. \end{align*}f′′(λ)​=var(Zλ​)=var(Zλ​−2a+b​)≤E[{Zλ​−2a+b​}2]≤4(b−a)2​.​

Plugging the above into (1)\textcolor{blue}{(1)}(1),
f(λ)=∫0λ∫0r(b−a)24ds dr=(b−a)24⋅λ22.f(\lambda) = \int_{0}^{\lambda} \int_{0}^{r} \frac{(b-a)^2}{4} ds \, dr = \frac{(b-a)^2}{4} \cdot \frac{\lambda^2}{2}.f(λ)=∫0λ​∫0r​4(b−a)2​dsdr=4(b−a)2​⋅2λ2​.

Hence, XXX is sub-Gaussian with parameter σ2=(b−a)24\sigma^2 = \frac{(b-a)^2}{4}σ2=4(b−a)2​.


Implication of the Theorem
By Chernoff, for any XXX whose support is contained in [a,b][a,b][a,b], we have
P{X−μ≥t}≤exp⁡{−2t2(b−a)2}.P \left\{ X- \mu \geq t \right\} \leq \exp \left\{ - \frac{2t^2}{(b-a)^2} \right\}.P{X−μ≥t}≤exp{−(b−a)22t2​}.

This inequality is known as Hoeffding’s inequality\textcolor{blue}{\text{Hoeffding's inequality}}Hoeffding’s inequality.

More general form of Hoeffding's inequality
Suppose that X1,X2,…,XnX_1,X_2,\dots, X_nX1​,X2​,…,Xn​ are independent RVs with support contained in [a,b][a,b][a,b]. In this case, we have
P{Xˉn−E[Xˉn]≥t}≤exp⁡{−2nt2(b−a)2},(2)P \left\{ \bar{X}_n - E[\bar{X}_n] \geq t \right\} \leq \exp \left\{ - \frac{2nt^2}{(b-a)^2} \right\}, \tag*{\textcolor{blue}{(2)}}P{Xˉn​−E[Xˉn​]≥t}≤exp{−(b−a)22nt2​},(2)

where Xˉn:=1n∑iXi\bar{X}_n := \frac{1}{n} \sum_i X_iXˉn​:=n1​∑i​Xi​ represents the sample mean.

We'll sketch the proof of the above in the special case where n=2n=2n=2. To do this, we'll show that if X1X_1X1​ and X2X_2X2​ are independent and sub-Gaussian with parameters σ12\sigma_1^2σ12​ and σ22\sigma_2^2σ22​, then X1+X2X_1+X_2X1​+X2​ is sub-Gaussian with parameter σ12+σ22\sigma_1^2 + \sigma_2^2σ12​+σ22​.

To see this,
MX1+X2(λ)=E[exp⁡{λ(X1+X2)}]=E[exp⁡{λX1}exp⁡{λX2}]=E[exp⁡{λX1}]E[exp⁡{λX2}]=MX1(λ)MX2(λ).\begin{align*} M_{X_1+X_2} (\lambda) &= E[\exp \{ \lambda(X_1 + X_2) \}] \\ &= E[\exp\{ \lambda X_1 \} \exp \{ \lambda X_2 \}] \\ &= E[\exp\{ \lambda X_1 \}] E[\exp\{ \lambda X_2 \}] \tag*{\purple{(\text{independence})}} \\ &= M_{X_1} (\lambda) M_{X_2}(\lambda). \end{align*}MX1​+X2​​(λ)​=E[exp{λ(X1​+X2​)}]=E[exp{λX1​}exp{λX2​}]=E[exp{λX1​}]E[exp{λX2​}]=MX1​​(λ)MX2​​(λ).​(independence)​

Similarly,
MX1+X2−E[X1+X2](λ)=MX1−E[X1](λ)⋅MX2−E[X2](λ).M_{X_1 + X_2 - E[X_1 + X_2]}(\lambda) = M_{X_1 - E[X_1]}(\lambda) \cdot M_{X_2 - E[X_2]}(\lambda).MX1​+X2​−E[X1​+X2​]​(λ)=MX1​−E[X1​]​(λ)⋅MX2​−E[X2​]​(λ).

By the sub-Gaussianity of X1X_1X1​ and X2X_2X2​, this implies
log⁡MX1+X2−E[X1+X2](λ)=log⁡MX1−E[X1](λ)+log⁡MX2−E[X2](λ)≤∑i=12λσi22=λ22∑i=12σi2.\begin{align*} \log M_{X_1 + X_2 - E[X_1 + X_2]}(\lambda) &= \log M_{X_1 - E[X_1]}(\lambda) + \log M_{X_2 - E[X_2]}(\lambda) \\ &\leq \sum_{i=1}^{2} \frac{\lambda \sigma_i^2}{2} \tag*{\purple{\text{(sub-Gaussianity of $X_1$ and $X_2$)}}} \\ &= \frac{\lambda^2}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{2} \sigma_i^2. \tag*{$[a_i, b_i]$} \end{align*}logMX1​+X2​−E[X1​+X2​]​(λ)​=logMX1​−E[X1​]​(λ)+logMX2​−E[X2​]​(λ)≤i=1∑2​2λσi2​​=2λ2​i=1∑2​σi2​.​(sub-Gaussianity of X1​ and X2​)[ai​,bi​]​

Hence, X1+X2X_1 + X_2X1​+X2​ is sub-Gaussian with parameter ∑i=12σi2\sum_{i=1}^{2} \sigma_i^2∑i=12​σi2​.

Combining this result with the preceding theorem and Chernoff's bound for sub-Gaussian RVs gives (2)\textcolor{blue}{(2)}(2) when n=2n=2n=2.

Sub-Exponential Random Variables

Definition. A random variable is called sub-exponential\textcolor{blue}{\text{sub-exponential}}sub-exponential with parameters (σ2,b)(\sigma^2,b)(σ2,b) if
log⁡MX−μ(λ)≤λ2σ22.E[exp⁡{λ(X−μ)}]\log M_{X-\mu} (\lambda) \leq \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2}. \tag*{\textcolor{gray}{$E[\exp\{ \lambda(X-\mu) \}]$}}logMX−μ​(λ)≤2λ2σ2​.E[exp{λ(X−μ)}]


Note: A sub-Gaussian random variable with parameter σ2\sigma^2σ2 is sub-exponential with parameters (σ2,b)(\sigma^2,b)(σ2,b) for any b>0b>0b>0.

An alternative characterization of sub-exponential random variables

A random variable XXX is sub-exponential if any only if there exist constants c>0c>0c>0and ℓ>0\ell>0ℓ>0 such that
P{∣X−μ∣≥t}≤cP{εℓ≥t}for all t>0,P \left\{ |X-\mu| \geq t \right\} \leq c P \left\{ \varepsilon_\ell \geq t \right\} \hspace{2em} \text{for all }t >0,P{∣X−μ∣≥t}≤cP{εℓ​≥t}for all t>0,

where εℓ∼Exp(ℓ)\varepsilon_\ell \sim \text{Exp}(\ell)εℓ​∼Exp(ℓ), so that P{εℓ≥t}=e−ℓtP\{ \varepsilon_\ell \geq t \} = e^{-\ell t}P{εℓ​≥t}=e−ℓt.

Theorem. If XXX is sub-exponential with parameters (σ2,b)(\sigma^2,b)(σ2,b), then, for all t≥0t\geq 0t≥0,
log⁡P{X−μ≥t}≤{−t22σ2,if 0≤t≤σ2b,−t2b,if t>σ2b.\log P \{ X-\mu \geq t \} \leq \begin{cases} -\frac{t^2}{2\sigma^2}, & \text{if } 0 \leq t \leq \frac{\sigma^2}{b}, \\ - \frac{t}{2b}, & \text{if } t>\frac{\sigma^2}{b}. \end{cases}logP{X−μ≥t}≤{−2σ2t2​,−2bt​,​if 0≤t≤bσ2​,if t>bσ2​.​



Proof. By Chernoff,
log⁡P{X≥μ+t}≤−sup⁡λ∈(0,1b)[λt−λ2σ22]⏟=:f(λ).(3)\log P \{ X \geq \mu + t \} \leq - \sup_{\lambda\in(0,\frac{1}{b})} \underbrace{\left[\lambda t - \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2}\right]}_{\blue{=: f(\lambda)}}. \tag*{\textcolor{green}{(3)}}logP{X≥μ+t}≤−λ∈(0,b1​)sup​=:f(λ)[λt−2λ2σ2​]​​.(3)

If we extend the definition of fff to the whole real line, we'd find that fff achieves its maximum at λ∗=tσ2\lambda^* = \frac{t}{\sigma^2}λ∗=σ2t​.

[image]

If t<σ2bt<\frac{\sigma^2}{b}t<bσ2​, then λ∗<1b\lambda^* <\frac{1}{b}λ∗<b1​, and so
sup⁡λ∈(0,1b)f(λ)=f(λ∗)=λ∗t−(λ∗)2σ22=t2σ22.\sup_{\lambda\in(0,\frac{1}{b})} f(\lambda) = f(\lambda^*) = \lambda^* t - \frac{(\lambda^*)^2 \sigma^2}{2} = \frac{t^2 \sigma^2}{2}.λ∈(0,b1​)sup​f(λ)=f(λ∗)=λ∗t−2(λ∗)2σ2​=2t2σ2​.

Plugging this into (3)\textcolor{green}{(3)}(3) gives the find bounds on the theorem statement.

If t≥σ2bt\geq \frac{\sigma^2}{b}t≥bσ2​, then λ∗≥1b\lambda^* \geq \frac{1}{b}λ∗≥b1​. Using that fff is monotone increasing on (0,1b)(0,\frac{1}{b})(0,b1​) (see picture above), it holds that
sup⁡λ∈(0,1b)f(λ)=(cont.of f)f(1b)=tb−σ22b2≥(σ2b≤t)t2b.\sup_{\lambda\in(0,\frac{1}{b})} f(\lambda) \stackrel{\scriptsize{\substack{\blue{(\text{cont.}} \\ \blue{\text{of }f)}}}}{=} f(\tfrac{1}{b}) = \frac{t}{b} - \frac{\sigma^2}{2b^2} \stackrel{\blue{(\tfrac{\sigma^2}{b} \leq t)}}{\geq} \frac{t}{2b}.λ∈(0,b1​)sup​f(λ)=(cont.of f)​f(b1​)=bt​−2b2σ2​≥(bσ2​≤t)​2bt​.

Combining this with (3)\textcolor{green}{(3)}(3) gives us the second bound.


Example: Bounded random variable.

Suppose XXX is bounded, so that ∣X−μ∣≤b|X-\mu| \leq b∣X−μ∣≤b a.s. for some b>0b>0b>0. Also, let σ2:=var(X)\sigma^2 := var(X)σ2:=var(X). We'll now show that XXX is sub-exponential with parameters (2σ2,2b)(2\sigma^2, 2b)(2σ2,2b).

From earlier: we know X is sub-Gaussian with parameter b2\blue{\text{From earlier: we know } X \text{ is sub-Gaussian with parameter } b^2}From earlier: we know X is sub-Gaussian with parameter b2.

We'll show this as follows:
MX−μ(λ)=E[exp⁡{λ(X−μ)}]=1+λ2σ22+∑k=3∞λkE[(X−μ)k]k!=1+λ2σ22+∑k=3∞λkE[(X−μ)2(X−μ)k−2⏞∣ ⋅ ∣≤bk−2]k!≤1+λ2σ22+λ2σ2∑k=3∞∣λ∣k−2bk−2k!≤1+λ2σ22+λ2σ2∑k=3∞(∣λ∣b)k−2=1+λ2σ22∑k=0∞(∣λ∣b)k.\begin{align*} M_{X-\mu}(\lambda) &= E \left[ \exp \{ \lambda(X-\mu) \} \right] \\ &= 1 + \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2} + \sum_{k=3}^{\infty} \lambda^k \frac{E[(X-\mu)^k]}{k!} \\ &= 1 + \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2} + \sum_{k=3}^{\infty} \lambda^k \frac{E[(X-\mu)^2 \overbrace{(X-\mu)^{k-2}}^{\purple{|\,\cdot\,| \leq b^{k-2}}}]}{k!} \\ &\leq 1 + \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2} +\lambda^2\sigma^2 \sum_{k=3}^{\infty} \frac{|\lambda|^{k-2} b^{k-2}}{k!} \\ &\leq 1 + \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2} + \lambda^2\sigma^2 \sum_{k=3}^{\infty} (|\lambda| b)^{k-2} \\ &= 1 + \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2} \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (|\lambda| b)^k. \end{align*}MX−μ​(λ)​=E[exp{λ(X−μ)}]=1+2λ2σ2​+k=3∑∞​λkk!E[(X−μ)k]​=1+2λ2σ2​+k=3∑∞​λkk!E[(X−μ)2(X−μ)k−2​∣⋅∣≤bk−2​]​≤1+2λ2σ2​+λ2σ2k=3∑∞​k!∣λ∣k−2bk−2​≤1+2λ2σ2​+λ2σ2k=3∑∞​(∣λ∣b)k−2=1+2λ2σ2​k=0∑∞​(∣λ∣b)k.​

If ∣λ∣b<1|\lambda| b < 1∣λ∣b<1, then the geometric series above converges, yielding
=1+λ2σ22(1−∣λ∣b)≤exp⁡[λ2σ22(1−∣λ∣b)].\begin{align*} &= 1 + \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2 (1 - |\lambda| b)} \tag*{$\orange{(4)}$} \\ &\leq \exp \left[ \frac{\lambda^2\sigma^2}{2(1 - |\lambda|b)} \right]. \end{align*}​=1+2(1−∣λ∣b)λ2σ2​≤exp[2(1−∣λ∣b)λ2σ2​].​(4)​

If ∣λ∣<12b|\lambda|< \frac{1}{2b}∣λ∣<2b1​, then 1−∣λ∣b>121-|\lambda| b > \frac{1}{2}1−∣λ∣b>21​, yielding
≤exp⁡[λ2σ2]\leq \exp [\lambda^2\sigma^2]≤exp[λ2σ2]

whenever ∣λ∣<12b|\lambda| < \frac{1}{2b}∣λ∣<2b1​. Hence, XXX is sub-exponential with parameters (2σ2,2b)(2\sigma^2, 2b)(2σ2,2b).


Theorem (Bernstein). Suppose XXX is a random variable that is such that ∣X−μ∣≤b|X - \mu| \leq b∣X−μ∣≤b a.s. Let σ2:=var(X)\sigma^2:= var(X)σ2:=var(X). For all t>0t>0t>0,
P{∣X−μ∣≥t}≤exp⁡[−t22{σ2+bt}].P \left\{ |X-\mu| \geq t \right\} \leq \exp \left[ - \frac{t^2}{2\{ \sigma^2 + bt \}} \right].P{∣X−μ∣≥t}≤exp[−2{σ2+bt}t2​].


Proof. By Chernoff and (4)\orange{\text{(4)}}(4), we have, for any λ∈[0,1b)\lambda\in[0,\frac{1}{b})λ∈[0,b1​),
log⁡P{X−μ≥t}≤−[λt−log⁡MX−μ(λ)]≤−[λt+λ2σ22(1−∣λ∣b)].\begin{align*} \log P \{ X-\mu \geq t \} &\leq - [\lambda t - \log M_{X-\mu}(\lambda)] \\ &\leq - \left[ \lambda t + \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2 (1-|\lambda|b)} \right]. \end{align*}logP{X−μ≥t}​≤−[λt−logMX−μ​(λ)]≤−[λt+2(1−∣λ∣b)λ2σ2​].​

Plugging in λ=tbt+σ2∈[0,1b)\lambda = \frac{t}{bt+\sigma^2}\in[0,\frac{1}{b})λ=bt+σ2t​∈[0,b1​) into the above given the result.


Similar calculations can be used to establish the following more general form of Bernstein's inequality.

Theorem (Bernstein). If X1,…,XnX_1,\dots,X_nX1​,…,Xn​ are independent random variables satisfying ∣Xi−μi∣≤b|X_i - \mu_i | \leq b∣Xi​−μi​∣≤b a.s. for all iii. Let σi2:=var(Xi)\sigma_i^2 := var(X_i)σi2​:=var(Xi​) and σˉn2:=1n∑i=1nσi2\bar{\sigma}^2_n := \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sigma_i^2σˉn2​:=n1​∑i=1n​σi2​. For all t>0t>0t>0,
P{Xˉn−E[Xˉn]≥t}≤exp⁡[−nt22[σˉn2+bt]].P \left\{ \bar{X}_n - E[\bar{X}_n] \geq t \right\} \leq \exp \left[ - \frac{nt^2}{\blue{2[\bar{\sigma}^2_n + bt]}} \right].P{Xˉn​−E[Xˉn​]≥t}≤exp[−2[σˉn2​+bt]nt2​].


Comparing this to Hoeffding:
P{Xˉn−E[Xˉn]≥t}≤exp⁡[−nt22b2].\begin{align*} P \left\{ \bar{X}_n - E[\bar{X}_n] \geq t \right\} \leq \exp \left[ - \frac{nt^2}{\blue{2b^2}} \right]. \end{align*}P{Xˉn​−E[Xˉn​]≥t}≤exp[−2b2nt2​].​

When comparing these two bounds, it is enough to simply compare the denominators shown in blue.

Some Notes:

  • Both inequalities suggest that deviations from the mean of larger than t=1nt=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}t=n​1​ are unlikely.

  • But: If σˉn2\bar{\sigma}_n^2σˉn2​ is small, then Bernstein's inequality can give much sharper bounds than Hoeffding.
    • Why? Well, if σˉn2\bar{\sigma}_n^2σˉn2​ and ttt are both small, then the denominator in Bernstein's inequality is also small (2[σˉn2+bt]\blue{2[\bar{\sigma}_n^2 + bt]}2[σˉn2​+bt]) — and, in particular, much small than the denominator in Hoeffding's inequality (2b2\blue{2b^2}2b2).


Bounded Differences Inequality

  • So far, we've been showing that a sample mean Xˉn\bar{X}_nXˉn​ is tightly concentrated about its mean E[Xˉn]E[\bar{X}_n]E[Xˉn​].

  • Now, we'll turn to more general cases where we have f:Xn→Rf: \mathcal{X}^n \to \mathbb{R}f:Xn→R and wish to derive upper bounds on
    P{∣f(X1n)−E[f(X1n)]∣≥t}P \left\{ | f(X_1^n) - E[f(X_1^n)] | \geq t \right\}P{∣f(X1n​)−E[f(X1n​)]∣≥t}

    (If we don't know anything about fff, we can't say anything here.)

  • A key example we'll study is the case where
    f(x1,x2,…,xn)⏟x1n:=sup⁡g∈G∣1n∑i=1n{g(Xi)−E[g(Xi)]}∣.f\underbrace{(x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n)}_{x_1^n} := \sup_{g\in G} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \left\{ g(X_i) - E[g(X_i)] \right\} \right|.fx1n​(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)​​:=g∈Gsup​​n1​i=1∑n​{g(Xi​)−E[g(Xi​)]}​.

    E.g. G={x↦1[x≥t]:t∈R}G = \left\{ x \mapsto \bold{1}[x\geq t]: t\in\mathbb{R} \right\}G={x↦1[x≥t]:t∈R}.

  • A function fff is said to satisfy the bounded differences property (BDP){\textcolor{blue}{\text{bounded differences property (BDP)}}}bounded differences property (BDP) with parameters c1,c2,…,cnc_1,c_2,\dots,c_nc1​,c2​,…,cn​ if, for all i∈{1,2,…,n}i \in \{ 1,2,\dots,n \}i∈{1,2,…,n} and all x1,x2,…,xn,xi′∈Xx_1,x_2,\dots,x_n, x_i' \in \mathcal{X}x1​,x2​,…,xn​,xi′​∈X:
    ∣f(x1,…,xi−1,xi,xi+1,…,xn)−f(x1,…,xi−1,xi′,xi+1,…,xn)∣≤ci.\left| f(x_1,\dots,x_{i-1}, \blue{x_i}, x_{i+1}, \dots, x_n) - f(x_1, \dots, x_{i-1}, \blue{x_i'}, x_{i+1}, \dots, x_n) \right| \leq c_i.∣f(x1​,…,xi−1​,xi​,xi+1​,…,xn​)−f(x1​,…,xi−1​,xi′​,xi+1​,…,xn​)∣≤ci​.

    (This is different than a Lipschitz condition. More about this at 26:00 in the Zoom lecture.)

  • This property enforces that fff can't depend too heavily on any one of its inputs.

We now revisit our example.

Example: Bounded random variable (continued).

f(x1n):=sup⁡g∈G∣1n∑i=1n{g(xi)−E[g(Xi)]}∣.f(x_1^n) := \sup_{g\in G} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \left\{ g(x_i) - E[g(X_i)] \right\} \right|.f(x1n​):=g∈Gsup​​n1​i=1∑n​{g(xi​)−E[g(Xi​)]}​.

We will require that the functions in GGG are uniformly bounded, and, in particular,
sup⁡g∈Gsup⁡x∈X∣g(x)∣≤1.\sup_{g\in G} \sup_{x\in\mathcal{X}} | g(x) | \leq 1.g∈Gsup​x∈Xsup​∣g(x)∣≤1.

We'll show that fff satisfies the BDP with parameters ci:=2nc_i := \frac{2}{n}ci​:=n2​ for all iii.

To see this, we'll use that, by the triangle inequality,
sup⁡t∣at∣−sup⁡∣bt∣≤sup⁡t∣at−bt∣.(★)\sup_t | a_t | - \sup |b_t| \leq \sup_t |a_t - b_t|. \tag*{\textcolor{lightgreen}{($\bigstar$)}}tsup​∣at​∣−sup∣bt​∣≤tsup​∣at​−bt​∣.(★)

We have that
f(x1n)−f(x1,…,xi−1,xi′,xi+1,…,xn)=sup⁡g∈G∣1n∑j=1n{g(xj)−E[g(Xj)]}∣−sup⁡g∈G∣1n∑j=1n{g(xj)−E[g(Xj)]}+1n{g(xi′)−g(xi)}∣≤sup⁡g∈G∣1n{g(xi)−g(xi′)}∣≤2n\begin{align*} f(x_1^n) &- f(x_1,\dots,x_{i-1}, x_i', x_{i+1}, \dots, x_n) \\ &= \sup_{g\in G} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \left\{ g(x_j) - E[g(X_j)] \right\} \right| \\ &\hspace{4em}- \sup_{g\in G} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \{ g(x_j) - E[g(X_j)] \} + \frac{1}{n} \left\{ g(x_i') - g(x_i) \right\} \right| \\ &\leq \sup_{g\in G} \left| \frac{1}{n} \{ g(x_i) - g(x_i') \} \right| \tag*{by \textcolor{lightgreen}{($\bigstar$)}} \\ &\leq \frac{2}{n} \tag{$g(x) \in [-1,1]$} \end{align*}f(x1n​)​−f(x1​,…,xi−1​,xi′​,xi+1​,…,xn​)=g∈Gsup​​n1​j=1∑n​{g(xj​)−E[g(Xj​)]}​−g∈Gsup​​n1​j=1∑n​{g(xj​)−E[g(Xj​)]}+n1​{g(xi′​)−g(xi​)}​≤g∈Gsup​​n1​{g(xi​)−g(xi′​)}​≤n2​​by (★)(g(x)∈[−1,1])​

By symmetry, we have ∣f(x1n)−f(x1,…,xi−1,xi′,xi+1,…,xn)≤2n|f(x_1^n) - f(x_1,\dots,x_{i-1}, x_i', x_{i+1},\dots, x_n) \leq \frac{2}{n}∣f(x1n​)−f(x1​,…,xi−1​,xi′​,xi+1​,…,xn​)≤n2​. Hence, the BDP holds with ci=2nc_i = \frac{2}{n}ci​=n2​.


Theorem (Bounded differences inequality; McDiarmid's inequality). If X1,…,XnX_1,\dots,X_nX1​,…,Xn​ are independent RVs and fff satisfies the BDP with parameters c1,…,cnc_1,\dots,c_nc1​,…,cn​, then, for all t>0t>0t>0,
P{∣f(X1n)−E[f(X1n)]∣≥t}≤2exp⁡{−2t2∑i=1nci2}.\blue{P \left\{ | f(X_1^n) - E[f(X_1^n)] | \geq t \right\}} \leq 2 \exp \left\{ - \frac{2t^2}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} c_i^2} \right\}.P{∣f(X1n​)−E[f(X1n​)]∣≥t}≤2exp{−∑i=1n​ci2​2t2​}.


Proof. Let
D1:=E[f(X1n)∣X1]−E[f(X)]Dj:=E[f(X1n)∣X1j]−E[f(X1n)∣X1j−1],j=2,3,…,n\begin{align*} D_1 := E[f(X_1^n) | X_1] - E[f(X)] \\ D_j := E[f(X_1^n) | X_1^j] - E[f(X_1^n) | X_1^{j-1}], \hspace{1em} j=2,3,\dots,n \end{align*}D1​:=E[f(X1n​)∣X1​]−E[f(X)]Dj​:=E[f(X1n​)∣X1j​]−E[f(X1n​)∣X1j−1​],j=2,3,…,n​

where X1j=X1,X2,…,XjX_1^j = \blue{X_1,X_2,\dots,X_j}X1j​=X1​,X2​,…,Xj​.

Note that
f(X1n)−E[f(X1n)]=∑j=1nDj.(telescoping sum)\blue{f(X_1^n) - E[f(X_1^n)]} = \green{\sum_{j=1}^{n} D_j} \tag*{\textcolor{red}{(telescoping sum)}}.f(X1n​)−E[f(X1n​)]=j=1∑n​Dj​.(telescoping sum)

Thus, to establish our desired result, it's enough to show that
P{∣∑j=1nDj∣≥t}≤2exp⁡{−2t2∑j=1ncj2}.(6)P \left\{ \left| \green{\sum_{j=1}^{n} D_j} \right| \geq t\right\} \leq 2 \exp \left\{ -\frac{2t^2}{\sum_{j=1}^{n} c_j^2} \right\}. \tag{6}P{​j=1∑n​Dj​​≥t}≤2exp{−∑j=1n​cj2​2t2​}.(6)

Note: DjD_jDj​ satisfies the following properties:

  1. DjD_jDj​ is a function of (X1,…,Xj)(X_1,\dots, X_j)(X1​,…,Xj​) and is independent of (Xj+1,…,Xn)(X_{j+1}, \dots, X_n)(Xj+1​,…,Xn​);

  2. E[Dj∣X1j−1]=E[E[f(X1n)∣X1j]−E[f(X1n)∣X1j−1]X1j−1∣]=0E[D_j | X_1^{j-1}] = E[E[f(X_1^n) | X_1^j] - E[f(X_1^n) | X_1^{j-1}] X_1^{j-1} |] = 0E[Dj​∣X1j−1​]=E[E[f(X1n​)∣X1j​]−E[f(X1n​)∣X1j−1​]X1j−1​∣]=0;

  3. E∣Dj∣<∞E|D_j|<\inftyE∣Dj​∣<∞.

Hence, {Dj}j=1n\{ D_j \}_{j=1}^{n}{Dj​}j=1n​ is a martingale difference sequence with respect to the filtration generated by X1,…,XjX_1, \dots, X_jX1​,…,Xj​.


Lemma (Azum-Hoeffding). (6)(6)(6) holds.

Proof. We'll repeatedly make use of the sub-Gaussianity of bounded random variables in this proof.

Towards the end of the proof, we'll have established that ∑j=1nDj\sum_{j=1}^{n} D_j∑j=1n​Dj​ is sub-Gaussian with parameter ∑j=1ncj24\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{n} c_j^2}{4}4∑j=1n​cj2​​.

To begin, note that Lj≤Dj≤UjL_j \leq D_j \leq U_jLj​≤Dj​≤Uj​, where
Lj:=inf⁡xjE[f(X1n)∣X1,…,Xj−1,Xj=xj]−E[f(X1n)∣X1j−1],Uj:=sup⁡xjE[f(X1n)∣X1j−1,Xj=xj]−E[f(X1n)∣X1j−1].\begin{align*} L_j &:= \inf_{x_j} E[f(X_1^n) | X_1,\dots,X_{j-1}, X_j = x_j] - E[f(X_1^n) | X_1^{j-1}], \\ U_j &:= \sup_{x_j} E[f(X_1^n) | X_1^{j-1}, X_j = x_j] - E[f(X_1^n) | X_1^{j-1}]. \end{align*}Lj​Uj​​:=xj​inf​E[f(X1n​)∣X1​,…,Xj−1​,Xj​=xj​]−E[f(X1n​)∣X1j−1​],:=xj​sup​E[f(X1n​)∣X1j−1​,Xj​=xj​]−E[f(X1n​)∣X1j−1​].​

Recalling that −inf⁡tat=sup⁡t[−at]-\inf_t a_t = \sup_t[-a_t]−inft​at​=supt​[−at​], we'll now use that fff satisfies the BDP to show that Uj−Lj≤cjU_j - L_j \leq c_jUj​−Lj​≤cj​:
Uj−Lj=sup⁡xj,xj′{E[f(X1n)∣X1j−1,Xj=xj]−E[f(X1n)∣X1j−1,Xj=xj′]}=sup⁡xj,xj′{E[f(X1j−1,xj,Xj+1n)∣X1j−1,Xj=xj]−E[f(X1j−1,xj,Xj+1n)∣X1j−1,Xj=xj′]}(due to independence)=sup⁡xj,xj′E[f(X1j−1,xj,Xj+1n)−f(X1j−1,xj′,Xj+1n)∣X1j−1]≤cj.\begin{align*} U_j - L_j &= \sup_{x_j, x_j'} \{ E[f(X_1^n) | X_1^{j-1}, X_j=x_j] - E[f(X_1^n) | X_1^{j-1}, X_j=x_j'] \} \\ &= \sup_{x_j, x_j'} \left\{ E \left[ f(X_1^{j-1}, x_j, X_{j+1}^n) | X_1^{j-1}, \cancel{X_j=x_j} \right] - E \left[ f(X_1^{j-1}, x_j, X_{j+1}^n) | X_1^{j-1}, \cancel{X_j=x_j'} \right] \right\} \\ &\hspace{7em} \text{(due to independence)} \\ &= \sup_{x_j, x_j'} E\left[ f(X_1^{j-1}, x_j, X_{j+1}^n) - f(X_1^{j-1}, x_j', X_{j+1}^n) \mid X_1^{j-1} \right] \\ &\leq c_j. \tag{BDP} \end{align*}Uj​−Lj​​=xj​,xj′​sup​{E[f(X1n​)∣X1j−1​,Xj​=xj​]−E[f(X1n​)∣X1j−1​,Xj​=xj′​]}=xj​,xj′​sup​{E[f(X1j−1​,xj​,Xj+1n​)∣X1j−1​,Xj​=xj​​]−E[f(X1j−1​,xj​,Xj+1n​)∣X1j−1​,Xj​=xj′​​]}(due to independence)=xj​,xj′​sup​E[f(X1j−1​,xj​,Xj+1n​)−f(X1j−1​,xj′​,Xj+1n​)∣X1j−1​]≤cj​.​(BDP)​

Note that through all of this, xj,xj′∈Xx_j, x_j' \in \mathcal{X}xj​,xj′​∈X.

Noting that Lj≤Dj≤UjL_j \leq D_j \leq U_jLj​≤Dj​≤Uj​ a.s. and also that LjL_jLj​ and UjU_jUj​ are only random through X1j−1X_1^{j-1}X1j−1​, we see that Dj∣X1j−1D_j | X_1^{j-1}Dj​∣X1j−1​ is sub-Gaussian with parameter σj2=cj24\sigma_j^2 = \frac{c_j^2}{4}σj2​=4cj2​​, in the sense that
E[exp⁡(λDj)∣X1j−1]≤exp⁡(λ2cj28).(★)E\left[ \exp(\lambda D_j) | X_1^{j-1} \right] \leq \exp \left( \frac{\lambda^2 c_j^2}{8} \right). \tag{$\bigstar$}E[exp(λDj​)∣X1j−1​]≤exp(8λ2cj2​​).(★)

Applying this result when j=nj=nj=n yields that
E[exp⁡(λ∑j=1nDj)]=E[E(exp⁡{λ∑j=1nDj}∣X1n−1)]=E[exp⁡{λ∑j=1nDj}E(exp⁡{λDn}∣X1n−1)]≤exp⁡(λ2cn28)E[exp⁡{λ∑j=1n−1Dj}].\begin{align*} E \left[ \exp \left( \lambda \green{\sum_{j=1}^{n} D_j} \right) \right] &= E \left[ E \left( \exp \left\{ \lambda \left. \sum_{j=1}^{n} D_j \right\} \right| X_1^{n-1} \right) \right] \\ &= E \left[ \exp \left\{ \lambda \sum_{j=1}^{n} D_j \right\} E \left( \exp \{ \lambda D_n \} | X_1^{n-1} \right) \right] \\ &\leq \exp \left( \frac{\lambda^2 c_n^2}{8} \right) E \left[ \exp \left\{ \lambda \sum_{j=1}^{n-1} D_j \right\} \right]. \end{align*}E[exp(λj=1∑n​Dj​)]​=E[E(exp{λj=1∑n​Dj​}​X1n−1​)]=E[exp{λj=1∑n​Dj​}E(exp{λDn​}∣X1n−1​)]≤exp(8λ2cn2​​)E[exp{λj=1∑n−1​Dj​}].​

Iterating this argument shows that
E[exp⁡(λ∑j=1nDj)]≤exp⁡(λ2∑j=1ncj28).E \left[ \exp \left( \lambda \green{\sum_{j=1}^{n} D_j} \right) \right] \leq \exp \left( \frac{\lambda^2 \sum_{j=1}^{n} c_j^2}{8} \right).E[exp(λj=1∑n​Dj​)]≤exp(8λ2∑j=1n​cj2​​).

Hence, we've shown that ∑j=1nDj\sum_{j=1}^{n} D_j∑j=1n​Dj​ is sub-Gaussian with parameter ∑j=1ncj24\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{n} c_j^2}{4}4∑j=1n​cj2​​. The result in the lemma follows by applying Chernoff twice, once to bound the probability of {∑j=1nDj≥t}\left\{ \green{\sum_{j=1}^{n} D_j} \geq t \right\}{∑j=1n​Dj​≥t} and again to bound that of {∑j=1nDj≥−t}\left\{ \green{\sum_{j=1}^{n} D_j} \geq -t \right\}{∑j=1n​Dj​≥−t}.
