Empirical Risk Minimization

  • Suppose that X1,X2,…,Xn∼iidPX_1,X_2,\dots,X_n\stackrel{iid}{\sim} PX1​,X2​,…,Xn​∼iidP

    • We'll let XXX denote a generic draw from PPP

  • Note that Pf:=EP[f(X)]Pf:= E_P[f(X)]Pf:=EP​[f(X)] and Pnf:=1n∑i=1nf(Xi)P_n f := \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} f(X_i)Pn​f:=n1​∑i=1n​f(Xi​)

  • We'll let ℓ:X×Θ→R\ell: \mathcal{X} \times \Theta \to \mathbb{R}ℓ:X×Θ→R and we'll assume that smaller values of the loss\textcolor{blue}{\text{loss}}loss are preferable.

  • Goal: Find a θ^∈Θ\hat{\theta} \in\Thetaθ^∈Θ such that the risk‾\textcolor{blue}{\underline{\text{risk}}}risk​
    ∫ℓ(x,θ^)dP(x)=:Pℓ( ⋅ ,θ^)\int \ell(x,\hat{\theta}) dP(x) =: P\ell(\,\cdot\,, \hat{\theta})∫ℓ(x,θ^)dP(x)=:Pℓ(⋅,θ^)

    that is nearly equal to
    inf⁡θ∈ΘPℓ( ⋅ ,θ).\inf_{\theta\in\Theta} P\ell(\,\cdot\,,\theta).θ∈Θinf​Pℓ(⋅,θ).

    To ease notation, I'll suppose the infimum is achieved at some θ0∈Θ\theta_0\in\Thetaθ0​∈Θ. Also, we'll write ℓ(θ)\ell(\theta)ℓ(θ) to denote x↦ℓ(x,θ)x \mapsto \ell(x,\theta)x↦ℓ(x,θ).

  • To quantify how close we are to achieving our goal, we'll consider the regret‾\textcolor{blue}{\underline{\text{regret}}}regret​:
    Reg(θ^):=Pℓ(θ^)−Pℓ(θ0)⏟=inf⁡θ∈ΘPℓ(θ).\text{Reg}(\hat{\theta}) := P \ell(\hat{\theta}) - \underbrace{P\ell(\theta_0)}_{\scriptsize{=\displaystyle\inf_{\theta\in\Theta} P\ell(\theta)}}.Reg(θ^):=Pℓ(θ^)−=θ∈Θinf​Pℓ(θ)Pℓ(θ0​)​​.

    Note: Reg(θ^)≥0\text{Reg}(\hat{\theta}) \geq 0Reg(θ^)≥0 and Reg(θ0)=0\text{Reg}(\theta_0)=0Reg(θ0​)=0.


How can we construct θ^?\hat{\theta}?θ^?
If we had access to PPP, then we can find θ0\theta_0θ0​ by simply solving
minimize  Pℓ(θ)subject to θ∈Θ.\text{minimize}\; \blue{P}\ell(\theta) \\ \text{subject to } \theta\in\Theta.minimizePℓ(θ)subject to θ∈Θ.

Since we don't know PPP, in practice we'll replace it by an estimate: the empirical distribution PnP_nPn​. So, our empirical risk minimizer‾\textcolor{blue}{\underline{\text{empirical risk minimizer}}}empirical risk minimizer​ θ^\hat{\theta}θ^ is a solution to
minimize  Pnℓ(θ)subject to θ∈Θ,\text{minimize}\; \blue{P_n}\ell(\theta) \\ \text{subject to } \theta\in\Theta,minimizePn​ℓ(θ)subject to θ∈Θ,

where Pnℓ(θ){P_n}\ell(\theta)Pn​ℓ(θ) is called the “empirical risk"\textcolor{blue}{\text{``empirical risk"}}“empirical risk".


Relation to M-estimation

  • Empirical risk minimization is a special case of M-estimation, which we say in STAT 581.
  • Often, when people use the term “M-estimation"\textcolor{blue}{\text{``M-estimation"}}“M-estimation" the objective is to establish a weak convergence\textcolor{magenta}{\text{weak convergence}}weak convergence result for θ^\hat{\theta}θ^.
    • Something like
      n(θ^−θ0)→dZ.\sqrt{n} (\hat{\theta}- \theta_0) \stackrel{d}{\to} Z.n​(θ^−θ0​)→dZ.
  • In contrast, when people use the term “empirical risk minimization"\textcolor{blue}{\text{``empirical risk minimization"}}“empirical risk minimization", the goal is to obtain a θ^\hat{\theta}θ^ with small regret\textcolor{magenta}{\text{small regret}}small regret (op(n−2/3)o_p(n^{-2/3})op​(n−2/3), for example(?)).

Example: Regression function.

  • Suppose X=(W,Y)X=(W,Y)X=(W,Y), where WWW is a feature and YYY is a real-valued outcome.

  • The goal is to predict YYY based on WWW.

  • Suppose Θ⊂L2(PW)\Theta\subset L^2(P_W)Θ⊂L2(PW​), where L2(PW)L^2(P_W)L2(PW​) consists of all f:W→Rf:\mathcal{W}\to\mathbb{R}f:W→R satisfying ∫f(w)2dPW⏟marg.dist’n(w)<∞\int f(w)^2 d \underbrace{P_W}_{\substack{\textcolor{blue}{\text{marg.}} \\ \textcolor{blue}{\text{dist'n}}}}(w) <\infty∫f(w)2dmarg.dist’n​PW​​​(w)<∞.

  • We'll use the squared error loss
    ℓ(x,θ):=[y−θ(w)]2,\ell(x,\theta):= [y-\theta(w)]^2,ℓ(x,θ):=[y−θ(w)]2,

    where x=(w,y)x=(w,y)x=(w,y)

  • If Θ\ThetaΘ contains w↦EP[Y∣W=w]w\mapsto E_P[Y|W=w]w↦EP​[Y∣W=w], then θ0\theta_0θ0​ is this function. Otherwise, θ0\theta_0θ0​ is the projection of w↦EP[Y∣W=w]w\mapsto E_P[Y|W=w]w↦EP​[Y∣W=w] onto Θ\ThetaΘ, in that
    θ0:=arg min⁡θ∈Θ∫{θ(w)−EP[Y∣W=w]}2dPW(w).\theta_0 := \argmin_{\theta\in\Theta} \int \left\{ \theta(w) - E_P[Y|W=w] \right\}^2 dP_W(w).θ0​:=θ∈Θargmin​∫{θ(w)−EP​[Y∣W=w]}2dPW​(w).


Example: Classification.

  • Same as the previous setting, except Y∈{0,1}Y\in\{ 0,1 \}Y∈{0,1} and the goal is to classify\textcolor{blue}{\text{classify}}classify YYY based on WWW.

    • Θ\ThetaΘ consists of maps from W\mathcal{W}W to {0,1}\{ 0,1 \}{0,1}.

  • Consider the 0-1 loss:
    ℓ(x,θ)=1[θ(w)≠y].\ell(x,\theta) = \bold{1}[\theta(w) \neq y].ℓ(x,θ)=1[θ(w)=y].

  • If Θ\ThetaΘ contains w↦1{EP[Y∣W=w]>12}w\mapsto \bold{1}\{ E_P[Y|W=w] > \frac{1}{2} \}w↦1{EP​[Y∣W=w]>21​}, then θ0\theta_0θ0​ can be taken to be equal to this function and
    Reg(θ)=EP[∣2EP[Y∣W]−1∣∣1{θ(W)≠θ0(W)}].\text{Reg}(\theta) = E_P [|2E_P[Y|W] - 1| \mid \bold{1} \{ \theta(W) \neq \theta_0(W) \}].Reg(θ)=EP​[∣2EP​[Y∣W]−1∣∣1{θ(W)=θ0​(W)}].


We now provide a template for analyzing
Reg(θ^):=Pℓ(θ^)−Pℓ(θ0)\text{Reg}(\hat{\theta}) := P\ell(\hat{\theta}) - P\ell(\theta_0)Reg(θ^):=Pℓ(θ^)−Pℓ(θ0​)

when θ^\hat{\theta}θ^ is an ERM.
(0≤) Reg(θ^):=Pℓ(θ^)−Pℓ(θ0)≤Pℓ(θ^)−Pℓ(θ0)+Pnℓ(θ0)−Pnℓ(θ^)⏟≥0=(Pn−P)[ℓ(θ0)−ℓ(θ^)]≤∣(Pn−P)ℓ(θ0)∣+∣(Pn−P)ℓ(θ^)∣≤2sup⁡θ∈Θ∣(Pn−P)ℓ(θ)∣=2sup⁡f∈F∣(Pn−P)f∣,\begin{align*} (0\leq ) \text{ Reg}(\hat{\theta}) &:= P\ell(\hat{\theta}) - P\ell(\theta_0) \\ &\leq P\ell(\hat{\theta}) - P\ell(\theta_0) + \underbrace{P_n \ell(\theta_0) - P_n\ell(\hat{\theta})}_{\purple{\geq 0}} \tag*{$\purple{(\hat{\theta} \text{ is an ERM})}$} \\ &= (P_n - P) [\ell(\theta_0)-\ell(\hat{\theta})] \\ &\leq \left|(P_n-P) \ell(\theta_0)\right| + \left|(P_n-P)\ell(\hat{\theta})\right| \tag*{$\purple{(\text{triangle ineq.})}$} \\ &\leq 2\sup_{\theta\in\Theta} \left| (P_n - P) \ell(\theta) \right| \tag*{$\purple{(\theta_0, \hat{\theta} \in \Theta)}$} \\ &= 2\sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} |(P_n - P)f|, \end{align*}(0≤) Reg(θ^)​:=Pℓ(θ^)−Pℓ(θ0​)≤Pℓ(θ^)−Pℓ(θ0​)+≥0Pn​ℓ(θ0​)−Pn​ℓ(θ^)​​=(Pn​−P)[ℓ(θ0​)−ℓ(θ^)]≤∣(Pn​−P)ℓ(θ0​)∣+​(Pn​−P)ℓ(θ^)​≤2θ∈Θsup​∣(Pn​−P)ℓ(θ)∣=2f∈Fsup​∣(Pn​−P)f∣,​(θ^ is an ERM)(triangle ineq.)(θ0​,θ^∈Θ)​

where F:={x↦ℓ(x,θ):θ∈Θ}\mathcal{F}:= \{ x\mapsto \ell(x,\theta) : \theta\in\Theta \}F:={x↦ℓ(x,θ):θ∈Θ}.

We've shown that
0≤Reg(θ^)≤2sup⁡f∈F∣(Pn−P)f∣⏟=:∥Pn−P∥F0\leq \text{Reg}(\hat{\theta}) \leq 2 \underbrace{\sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} |(P_n-P)f|}_{\blue{=: \Vert P_n-P \Vert_{\mathcal{F}}}}0≤Reg(θ^)≤2=:∥Pn​−P∥F​f∈Fsup​∣(Pn​−P)f∣​​


Rademacher Complexity

  • Suppose F\mathcal{F}F consists of [0,1][0,1][0,1]-valued functions.

    • From our example in Chapter 3, we know that ∥Pn−P∥F\Vert P_n - P \Vert_{\mathcal{F}}∥Pn​−P∥F​ satisfies the BDP with parameters ci=1nc_i = \frac{1}{n}ci​=n1​, i∈{1,2,…,n}i\in\{1,2,\dots,n\}i∈{1,2,…,n}.

  • Hence, by McDiarmid's inequality, for all t>0t>0t>0,
    P{∣∥Pn−P∥F−E∥Pn−P∥F∣≥t}≤2exp⁡{−2nt2}.P \left\{ \left| \Vert P_n - P\Vert_\mathcal{F} - E\Vert P_n - P\Vert_{\mathcal{F}} \right|\geq t \right\} \leq 2 \exp \{ -2nt^2 \}.P{∣∥Pn​−P∥F​−E∥Pn​−P∥F​∣≥t}≤2exp{−2nt2}.

    So, with high probability, ∥Pn−P∥F\Vert P_n - P\Vert_\mathcal{F}∥Pn​−P∥F​ is close to its mean!

    • To get a high-probability bound on ∥Pn−P∥F\Vert P_n - P \Vert_{\mathcal{F}}∥Pn​−P∥F​, it's enuogh to get a high-probability bound on E∥Pn−P∥FE\Vert P_n - P \Vert_\mathcal{F}E∥Pn​−P∥F​.

Symmetrization argument to bound E∥Pn−P∥FE\Vert P_n - P\Vert_\mathcal{F}E∥Pn​−P∥F​

  • Let X1,X2,…,Xn,X1′,X2′,…,Xn′∼iidPX_1,X_2,\dots,X_n, X_1', X_2', \dots, X_n'\stackrel{iid}{\sim} PX1​,X2​,…,Xn​,X1′​,X2′​,…,Xn′​∼iidP.
    • X1,X2,…,XnX_1,X_2,\dots,X_nX1​,X2​,…,Xn​ is our original sample
    • X1′,X2′,…,Xn′X_1', X_2', \dots, X_n'X1′​,X2′​,…,Xn′​ is called a ghost sample\textcolor{blue}{\text{ghost sample}}ghost sample
  • Let Pn′P_n'Pn′​ denote the empirical distribution of X1′,X2′,…,Xn′X_1',X_2',\dots,X_n'X1′​,X2′​,…,Xn′​.

We have that
E∥Pn−P∥F=E[sup⁡f∈F∣1n∑i=1nf(Xi)−EP[f(Xi′)]∣]=E{∣sup⁡f∈FE[1n∑i=1n{f(Xi)−f(Xi′)}∣X1n]∣}≤E{E[sup⁡f∈F∣1n∑i=1n{f(Xi)−f(Xi′)}∣X1n]}=E[sup⁡f∈F∣1n∑i=1n{f(Xi)−f(Xi′)}∣].\begin{align*} E\Vert P_n - P \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} &= E \left[ \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} f(X_i) - E_P[f(X_i')] \right| \right] \\ &= E \left\{ \left| \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} E \left[ \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \{ f(X_i) - f(X_i') \} | X_1^n \right] \right| \right\} \tag*{\purple{(\text{linearity of expectation})}} \\ &\leq E \left\{ E \left[ \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \{ f(X_i) - f(X_i') \} \right| X_1^n \right] \right\} \\ &= E \left[ \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \{ f(X_i) - f(X_i') \} \right| \right]. \end{align*}E∥Pn​−P∥F​​=E[f∈Fsup​​n1​i=1∑n​f(Xi​)−EP​[f(Xi′​)]​]=E{​f∈Fsup​E[n1​i=1∑n​{f(Xi​)−f(Xi′​)}∣X1n​]​}≤E{E[f∈Fsup​​n1​i=1∑n​{f(Xi​)−f(Xi′​)}​X1n​]}=E[f∈Fsup​​n1​i=1∑n​{f(Xi​)−f(Xi′​)}​].​(linearity of expectation)​

Let ε1,…,εn∼iidRademacher\varepsilon_1,\dots,\varepsilon_n \stackrel{iid}{\sim} \text{Rademacher}ε1​,…,εn​∼iidRademacher that are independent X1,X2,…,Xn,X1′,X2′,…,Xn′X_1,X_2,\dots,X_n, X_1',X_2',\dots,X_n'X1​,X2​,…,Xn​,X1′​,X2′​,…,Xn′​. Since X1,X2,…,Xn,X1′,X2′,…,Xn′∼iidPX_1,X_2,\dots,X_n,X_1',X_2',\dots,X_n'\stackrel{iid}{\sim} PX1​,X2​,…,Xn​,X1′​,X2′​,…,Xn′​∼iidP, we can continue the above as
=E[sup⁡f∈F∣1n∑i=1nεi{f(Xi)−f(Xi′)}∣]≤E[sup⁡f∈F∣1n∑i=1nεif(Xi)∣]+E[sup⁡f∈F∣1n∑i=1nεif(Xi′)∣]=2E[sup⁡f∈F∣1n∑i=1nεif(Xi)∣].\begin{align*} &= E \left[ \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \varepsilon_i \left\{ f(X_i) - f(X_i') \right\} \right| \right] \\ &\leq E \left[ \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \varepsilon_i f(X_i) \right| \right] + E \left[ \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \varepsilon_i f(X_i') \right| \right]\\ &= 2 E \left[ \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \varepsilon_i f(X_i) \right| \right]. \end{align*}​=E[f∈Fsup​​n1​i=1∑n​εi​{f(Xi​)−f(Xi′​)}​]≤E[f∈Fsup​​n1​i=1∑n​εi​f(Xi​)​]+E[f∈Fsup​​n1​i=1∑n​εi​f(Xi′​)​]=2E[f∈Fsup​​n1​i=1∑n​εi​f(Xi​)​].​

To write this more cleanly, we'll define the Rademacher process\textcolor{blue}{\text{Rademacher process}}Rademacher process Rn:F→RR_n: \mathcal{F}\to\mathbb{R}Rn​:F→R as
Rn(f):=1n∑i=1nεif(Xi).R_n(f) := \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \varepsilon_i f(X_i).Rn​(f):=n1​i=1∑n​εi​f(Xi​).

Also let ∥Rn∥F:=sup⁡f∈F∣Rn(f)∣\Vert R_n \Vert_\mathcal{F} := \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} |R_n(f)|∥Rn​∥F​:=supf∈F​∣Rn​(f)∣. Hence, we've shown that
E∥Pn−P∥F⏟“empirical process term"≤2E∥Rn∥F⏟the “Rademachercomplexity of F".\underbrace{E\Vert P_n -P \Vert_{\mathcal{F}}}_{\text{``empirical process term"}} \leq 2 \underbrace{E \Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}}}_{\substack{\text{the ``Rademacher} \\ \text{complexity of } \mathcal{F} \;\!"}}.“empirical process term"E∥Pn​−P∥F​​​≤2the “Rademachercomplexity of F"​E∥Rn​∥F​​​.

Often, when studying E∥Rn∥FE\Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}}E∥Rn​∥F​, we use that
E∥Rn∥F=E{E[∥Rn∥F∣X1n]}⏟“empirical Rademachercomplexity".E\Vert R_n \Vert_\mathcal{F} = E \underbrace{\left\{ {E [\Vert R_n \Vert_\mathcal{F} | X_1^n]} \right\}}_{\textcolor{blue}{\substack{\text{``empirical Rademacher} \\ \text{complexity"}}}}.E∥Rn​∥F​=E“empirical Rademachercomplexity"​{E[∥Rn​∥F​∣X1n​]}​​.


Almost-matching lower bound via desymmetrization

E∥Pn−P∥F≥12E∥Rn∥F−log⁡(2)2n.E \Vert P_n - P \Vert_\mathcal{F} \geq \frac{1}{2} E \Vert R_n \Vert_\mathcal{F} - \sqrt{\frac{\log(2)}{2n}}.E∥Pn​−P∥F​≥21​E∥Rn​∥F​−2nlog(2)​​.

Putting together what we've seen today gives the following theorem.

Theorem. If F\mathcal{F}F is a collection of [0,1][0,1][0,1]-valued functions, then, with probability at least 1−2exp⁡(−2nt2)1-2\exp (-2nt^2)1−2exp(−2nt2),
12E∥Rn∥F−log⁡(2)2n≤E∥Pn−P∥F−t≤∥Pn−P∥F≤E∥Pn−P∥F+t≤2E∥Pn−P∥F+t.\begin{align*} \frac{1}{2} E \Vert R_n \Vert_\mathcal{F} - \sqrt{\frac{\log(2)}{2n}} &\leq E\Vert P_n-P \Vert_\mathcal{F} - t \\ &\leq \Vert P_n - P \Vert_\mathcal{F} \tag{$(P_n-P)f = O_p(1/\sqrt{n})$} \\ &\leq E\Vert P_n - P \Vert_\mathcal{F} + t \\ &\leq 2 E\Vert P_n - P \Vert_\mathcal{F} + t. \end{align*}21​E∥Rn​∥F​−2nlog(2)​​​≤E∥Pn​−P∥F​−t≤∥Pn​−P∥F​≤E∥Pn​−P∥F​+t≤2E∥Pn​−P∥F​+t.​((Pn​−P)f=Op​(1/n​))​



Vapnik-Chervonenkis (VC) dimension

  • Let F\mathcal{F}F be a class of functions mapping from X\mathcal{X}X to {0,1}\{ 0,1 \}{0,1}.

  • For x1n=(x1,x2,…,xn)∈Xnx_1^n = (x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n) \in\mathcal{X}^nx1n​=(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)∈Xn, define the projection of F onto x1n\textcolor{blue}{\text{projection of } \mathcal{F} \text{ onto } x_1^n}projection of F onto x1n​ as
    Fx1n:={(f(x1),f(x2),…,f(xn)):f∈F}.\mathcal{F}_{x_1^n} := \left\{ (f(x_1), f(x_2),\dots,f(x_n)): f\in\mathcal{F} \right\}.Fx1n​​:={(f(x1​),f(x2​),…,f(xn​)):f∈F}.

    • Hence, ∣Fx1n∣≤2n|\mathcal{F}_{x_1^n}|\leq 2^n∣Fx1n​​∣≤2n
    • We say that F\mathcal{F}F shatters\textcolor{blue}{\text{shatters}}shatters x1nx_1^nx1n​ if ∣Fx1n∣=2n|\mathcal{F}_{x_1^n}|=2^n∣Fx1n​​∣=2n.

  • Define the growth function\textcolor{blue}{\text{growth function}}growth function of F\mathcal{F}F as
    ΠF(n):=sup⁡x1n∈Xn∣Fx1n∣.\Pi_\mathcal{F}(n) := \sup_{x_1^n\in\mathcal{X}^n} | \mathcal{F}_{x_1^n}|.ΠF​(n):=x1n​∈Xnsup​∣Fx1n​​∣.

  • The VC dimension\textcolor{blue}{\text{VC dimension}}VC dimension of F\mathcal{F}F is defined as
    VC(F):=sup⁡{n∈N:ΠF(n)=2n},VC(\mathcal{F}) := \sup \left\{ n\in\mathbb{N}: \Pi_{\mathcal{F}}(n) = 2^n \right\},VC(F):=sup{n∈N:ΠF​(n)=2n},

    where the right hand side represents:
    “the largest n such that there exists a tuple x1n that is shattered by F".\textcolor{orange}{\text{``the largest } n \text{ such that there exists a tuple } x_1^n \text{ that is shattered by } \mathcal{F}}".“the largest n such that there exists a tuple x1n​ that is shattered by F".

    • It's possible that VC(F)=+∞VC(\mathcal{F}) = +\inftyVC(F)=+∞.
    • The VC index\textcolor{blue}{\text{VC index}}VC index of F\mathcal{F}F is defined as
      VC(F)+1.VC(\mathcal{F})+1.VC(F)+1.

    Why will studying the VC dimension by useful?

    • Well, we're trying to study
      ∥Pn−P∥F:=sup⁡f∈F∣1n∑i=1nf(Xi)−Pf∣\Vert P_n - P\Vert_\mathcal{F} := \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} f(X_i) - Pf \right|∥Pn​−P∥F​:=f∈Fsup​​n1​i=1∑n​f(Xi​)−Pf​

We can also define the VC dimension (or VC index) of a collection of sets.

  • Let A\mathcal{A}A denote the collection of subsets of X\mathcal{X}X. Define
    FA={x↦1B(x):B∈A}.\mathcal{F}_\mathcal{A} = \left\{ x\mapsto \bold{1}_B(x): B\in\mathcal{A} \right\}.FA​={x↦1B​(x):B∈A}.

    We then let
    VC(A):=VC(FA)ΠA(n):=ΠFA(n).VC(\mathcal{A}) := VC(\mathcal{F}_\mathcal{A}) \\ \Pi_\mathcal{A}(n) := \Pi_{\mathcal{F}_\mathcal{A}}(n).VC(A):=VC(FA​)ΠA​(n):=ΠFA​​(n).

Suppose now that F\mathcal{F}F consists of X→R\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R}X→R functions. The VC dimension of F\mathcal{F}F is defined as the VC dimension of the class of subgraphs A\mathcal{A}A:
A:={{(x,t)∈X×R:t<f(x)}:f∈F}\mathcal{A} := \left\{ {\{ (x,t)\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathbb{R}: t< f(x)\}}: f\in\mathcal{F} \right\}A:={{(x,t)∈X×R:t<f(x)}:f∈F}

Theorem. Consider a parameterized family of functions
F:={x↦g(x,θ):θ∈Rp},\mathcal{F} := \{ x\mapsto g(x,\theta): \theta\in\mathbb{R}^p \},F:={x↦g(x,θ):θ∈Rp},

where g:Rm×Rp→{0,1}g:\mathbb{R}^m \times\mathbb{R}^p \to \{ 0,1 \}g:Rm×Rp→{0,1}. Suppose ggg can be computed using no more than ttt operations of the following types:

  1. arithmetic (+++, −-−, ×\times×, ÷\div÷)
  2. comparisons of real numbers (>>>, ≥\geq≥, ===, <<<, ≤\leq≤, ≠\neq=).

Then VC(F)≤4p(t+2)VC(\mathcal{F}) \leq 4p(t+2)VC(F)≤4p(t+2).


Quick Detour: Bracketing and Covering Numbers.

  • Let F\mathcal{F}F be a subset of an L(P)L^(P)L(P) space.

    • For r≥1r\geq 1r≥1, Lr(P)L^r(P)Lr(P) is the space of functions f:X→Rf: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}f:X→R such that
      ∥f∥Lr(P):=[∫∣f(x)∣rdP(x)]1/r<∞.\Vert f \Vert_{L^r(P)} := \left[ \int |f(x)|^r dP(x) \right]^{1/r} <\infty.∥f∥Lr(P)​:=[∫∣f(x)∣rdP(x)]1/r<∞.

      When r=∞r=\inftyr=∞, Lr(P)L^r(P)Lr(P) consists of f:X→Rf:\mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}f:X→R such that
      ∥f∥L∞(P):=esssup⁡P∣f(x)∣:=inf⁡{a∈R:P[∣f(X)∣>a]=0}<∞.\begin{align*} \Vert f \Vert_{L^\infty(P)} &:= {\text{ess}\sup}_P |f(x)| \\ &:= \inf \left\{ a\in\mathbb{R}: P[|f(X)| > a] = 0 \right\} \\ &< \infty. \end{align*}∥f∥L∞(P)​​:=esssupP​∣f(x)∣:=inf{a∈R:P[∣f(X)∣>a]=0}<∞.​

    • For any f:X→Rf:\mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}f:X→R,
      ∥f∥Lr(P)≤∥f∥Lq(P)if r≤q.\begin{align*} \Vert f\Vert_{L^r(P)} \leq \Vert f \Vert_{L^q(P)} \hspace{2em} \text{if } r\leq q. \\ \\ \end{align*}∥f∥Lr(P)​≤∥f∥Lq(P)​if r≤q.​

ε\varepsilonε-bracketing Numbers

  • Given two functions ℓ:X→R\ell: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}ℓ:X→R and u:X→Ru: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}u:X→R, the bracket\textcolor{blue}{\text{bracket}}bracket [ℓ,u][\ell,u][ℓ,u] is defined as
    [ℓ,u]:={f∈Lr(P):ℓ≤f≤u pointwise}.[\ell,u] := \left\{ f\in L^r(P): \ell \leq f \leq u \text{ pointwise} \right\}.[ℓ,u]:={f∈Lr(P):ℓ≤f≤u pointwise}.

  • We call [ℓ,u][\ell,u][ℓ,u] and ε-bracket\textcolor{blue}{\varepsilon\text{-bracket}}ε-bracket if ∥u−ℓ∥Lr(P)≤ε\Vert u-\ell \Vert_{L^r(P)} \leq \varepsilon∥u−ℓ∥Lr(P)​≤ε.

  • The ε-bracketing number\textcolor{blue}{\varepsilon\text{-bracketing number}}ε-bracketing number N[](ε,F,Lr(P))N_{[]}(\varepsilon, \mathcal{F}, L^r(P))N[]​(ε,F,Lr(P)) of F\mathcal{F}F is defined as the minimal number of ε-brackets\varepsilon\text{-brackets}ε-brackets needed to cover F\mathcal{F}F, that is
    N[](ε,F,Lr(P)):=inf⁡{m:F⊆⋃j=1m[ℓj,uj] for a collection of ε-brackets [ℓj,uj],j=1,…,m}\small{N_{[]}(\varepsilon, \mathcal{F}, L^r(P)) := \inf \left\{ m: \mathcal{F} \subseteq \bigcup_{j=1}^{m} [\ell_j, u_j] \text{ for a collection of } \varepsilon\text{-brackets } [\ell_j, u_j], j=1,\dots,m \right\}}N[]​(ε,F,Lr(P)):=inf{m:F⊆j=1⋃m​[ℓj​,uj​] for a collection of ε-brackets [ℓj​,uj​],j=1,…,m}

Definition. A function d:S×S→[0,∞)d: S\times S \to [0,\infty)d:S×S→[0,∞) is called a pseudometric\textcolor{blue}{\text{pseudometric}}pseudometric on SSS if:

  1. d(x,x)=0d(x,x) =0d(x,x)=0 for all x∈Sx\in Sx∈S;
  2. d(x,y)=d(y,x)d(x,y) = d(y,x)d(x,y)=d(y,x) for all x,y∈Sx,y\in Sx,y∈S;
  3. d(y,z)≤d(y,x)+d(x,z)d(y,z) \leq d(y,x) + d(x,z)d(y,z)≤d(y,x)+d(x,z) for all x,y,z∈Sx,y,z\in Sx,y,z∈S.

In contrast to a metric, d(x,y)d(x,y)d(x,y) may be equal to 0 even if x≠yx\neq yx=y.

A pseudometric space\textcolor{blue}{\text{pseudometric space}}pseudometric space (S,d)(S,d)(S,d) is a pairing of a set SSS with a pseudometric on that set, e.g. d(f,g):=∥f−g∥Lr(P)d(f,g) := \Vert f - g \Vert_{L^r(P)}d(f,g):=∥f−g∥Lr(P)​.



Covering Numbers

  • Let (S,d)(S,d)(S,d) denote a pseudometric space and T⊆ST\subseteq ST⊆S.
  • A set T1⊆ST_1 \subseteq ST1​⊆S in called an ε-cover\textcolor{blue}{\varepsilon\text{-cover}}ε-cover of TTT if, for all θ1∈T1\theta_1\in T_1θ1​∈T1​ such that d(θ,θ1)≤εd(\theta, \theta_1) \leq \varepsilond(θ,θ1​)≤ε.
  • The ε-covering number\textcolor{blue}{\varepsilon\text{-covering number}}ε-covering number is defined as the size of the minimal ε-cover\varepsilon\text{-cover}ε-cover:
    N(ε,T,d)=inf⁡{∣T1∣:T1 is an ε-cover of T}.N(\varepsilon, T, d) = \inf \left\{ |T_1|: T_1 \text{ is an } \varepsilon\text{-cover of } T \right\}.N(ε,T,d)=inf{∣T1​∣:T1​ is an ε-cover of T}.

Our goal will be to show that, if F\mathcal{F}F is a VC class of boolean valued functions, then
E∥Pn−P∥F=O(log⁡(n)n).E\Vert P_n - P \Vert_\mathcal{F} = O \left( \sqrt{\frac{\log(n)}{n}} \right).E∥Pn​−P∥F​=O(nlog(n)​​).

Lemma (Finite class lemma). If F\mathcal{F}F is a class X→[−1,1]\mathcal{X} \to [-1,1]X→[−1,1] then
E∥Rn∥F≤2log⁡(2E[∣Fx1n∣])n,,(1)\blue{E\Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} \leq \sqrt{\frac{2\log(2E[|F_{x_1^n}|])}{n}}}, \tag*{$\blue{(1)}$},E∥Rn​∥F​≤n2log(2E[∣Fx1n​​∣])​​,,(1)

where Fx1n:={(f(X1),f(X2),…,f(Xn)):f∈F}\mathcal{F}_{x_1^n} := \left\{ (f(X_1), f(X_2), \dots, f(X_n)): f\in\mathcal{F} \right\}Fx1n​​:={(f(X1​),f(X2​),…,f(Xn​)):f∈F}d.

Proof. In what follows, we'll establish that, for PPP-almost all x1n∈Xnx_1^n\in\mathcal{X}^nx1n​∈Xn,
E[∥Rn∥F∣X1n=x1n]≤2log⁡(2∣Fx1n∣)n..(2)E \left[ \Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} \mid X_1^n = x_1^n \right] \leq \sqrt{\frac{2\log(2|F_{x_1^n}|)}{n}}. \tag*{$\orange{(2)}$}.E[∥Rn​∥F​∣X1n​=x1n​]≤n2log(2∣Fx1n​​∣)​​..(2)

This will yield (1)\blue{(1)}(1) after integrating both sides against PnP^nPn and applying Jensen's inequality.

We now establish (2)\orange{(2)}(2). For z∈[−1,1]nz\in[-1,1]^nz∈[−1,1]n, we'll let ⟨ε,z⟩=∑j=1nεjzj\langle \varepsilon, z \rangle = \sum_{j=1}^{n} \varepsilon_j z_j⟨ε,z⟩=∑j=1n​εj​zj​. Let
Zx1n=Fx1n  ⋃(−Fx1n)⏟:={−z:z∈Fx1n}.\mathcal{Z}_{x_1^n} = \mathcal{F}_{x_1^n} \;\bigcup \underbrace{(-\mathcal{F}_{x_1^n})}_{\purple{:= \left\{ -z: z\in\mathcal{F}_{x_1^n}\right\}}}.Zx1n​​=Fx1n​​⋃:={−z:z∈Fx1n​​}(−Fx1n​​)​​.

For any λ>0\lambda>0λ>0,
exp⁡{λE[sup⁡f∈F∣⟨ε,f(x1n)⟩]}=exp⁡{λE[sup⁡z∈Zx1n⟨ε,z⟩]}≤E[exp⁡{λsup⁡z∈Zx1n⟨ε,z⟩}]=E[sup⁡z∈Zx1nexp⁡{λ⟨ε,z⟩}]≤∑z∈Zx1nE[exp⁡{λ⟨ε,z⟩}]⏟MGF of ⟨ε,z⟩!\begin{align*} \exp \left\{ \lambda E \left[ \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} | \langle \varepsilon, f(x_1^n) \rangle \right] \right\} &= \exp \left\{ \lambda E \left[ \sup_{z\in\mathcal{Z}_{x_1^n}} \langle \varepsilon, z \rangle \right] \right\} \tag*{$\purple{|a| = \max\{ -a,a \}}$} \\ &\leq E \left[ \exp \left\{ \lambda \sup_{z\in\mathcal{Z}_{x_1^n}} \langle \varepsilon, z \rangle \right\} \right] \tag*{$\purple{\text{Jensen's inequality}}$} \\ &= E \left[ \sup_{z\in\mathcal{Z}_{x_1^n}} \exp \left\{ \lambda \langle \varepsilon, z \rangle \right\} \right] \tag*{$\purple{\text{monotonicity of } \exp\{ \lambda \, \cdot \}}$} \\ &\leq \sum_{z\in\mathcal{Z}_{x_1^n}} \underbrace{E \left[ \exp \{ \lambda \langle \varepsilon, z \rangle \} \right]}_{\purple{\text{MGF of } \langle \varepsilon, z \rangle}!} \end{align*}exp{λE[f∈Fsup​∣⟨ε,f(x1n​)⟩]}​=exp{λE[z∈Zx1n​​sup​⟨ε,z⟩]}≤E[exp{λz∈Zx1n​​sup​⟨ε,z⟩}]=E[z∈Zx1n​​sup​exp{λ⟨ε,z⟩}]≤z∈Zx1n​​∑​MGF of ⟨ε,z⟩!E[exp{λ⟨ε,z⟩}]​​​∣a∣=max{−a,a}Jensen’s inequalitymonotonicity of exp{λ⋅}​

Because εizi\varepsilon_i z_iεi​zi​ is a random variable bounded in [−1,1][-1,1][−1,1], it is sub-Gaussian with parameter 111. Hence, the iid sum ⟨ε,z⟩\langle \varepsilon, z \rangle⟨ε,z⟩ is sub-Gaussian with parameter nnn.

Plugging this into the above, we have
exp⁡{λE[sup⁡f∈F∣⟨ε,f(x1n)⟩∣]}≤∑z∈Zx1nexp⁡(λ2n2)=∣Zx1n∣exp⁡(λ2n2).\begin{align*} \exp \left\{ \lambda E \left[ \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \langle \varepsilon, f(x_1^n) \rangle \right| \right] \right\} &\leq \sum_{z\in\mathcal{Z}_{x_1^n}} \exp \left( \frac{\lambda^2 n}{2} \right) \\ &= \left| \mathcal{Z}_{x_1^n} \right| \exp \left( \frac{\lambda^2 n}{2} \right). \end{align*}exp{λE[f∈Fsup​∣⟨ε,f(x1n​)⟩∣]}​≤z∈Zx1n​​∑​exp(2λ2n​)=​Zx1n​​​exp(2λ2n​).​

Hence,
E[sup⁡f∈F∣⟨ε,f(x1n)⟩∣]≤log⁡∣Zx1n∣λ+λn2.E \left[ \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \langle \varepsilon, f(x_1^n) \rangle \right| \right] \leq \frac{\log \left| \mathcal{Z}_{x_1^n} \right|}{\lambda} + \frac{\lambda_n}{2}.E[f∈Fsup​∣⟨ε,f(x1n​)⟩∣]≤λlog​Zx1n​​​​+2λn​​.

Plugging in λ=2log⁡∣Zx1n∣n\lambda = \sqrt{\frac{2\log \left| \mathcal{Z}_{x_1^n}\right|}{n}}λ=n2log​Zx1n​​​​​ and using that ∣Zx1n∣≤2∣Fx1n∣\left| \mathcal{Z}_{x_1^n} \right| \leq 2 \left| \mathcal{F}_{x_1^n} \right|​Zx1n​​​≤2​Fx1n​​​ gives (2)\orange{(2)}(2).


By the above lemma and the definition of the growth function, when F\mathcal{F}F consists of boolean-valued functions,
E∥Pn−P∥F≤2E∥Rn∥F≤22log⁡(2E[∣Fx1n])n≤22log⁡(2sup⁡x1n∣Fx1n∣)nwhere ΠF(n)=sup⁡x1n∣Fx1n∣=22log⁡(2ΠF(n))n.\begin{align*} E\Vert P_n - P \Vert_\mathcal{F} &\leq 2 E \Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} \\ &\leq 2 \sqrt{ \frac{2\log (2 E[|\mathcal{F}_{x_1^n}])}{n}} \\ &\leq 2 \sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(2\sup_{x_1^n} |\mathcal{F}_{x_1^n}|\right)}{n}} \hspace{2em} \blue{\text{where } \Pi_{\mathcal{F}}(n) = \sup_{x_1^n} |\mathcal{F}_{x_1^n}|} \\ &= 2 \sqrt{\frac{2\log(2\Pi_\mathcal{F}(n))}{n}}. \tag*{$\red{(3)}$} \end{align*}E∥Pn​−P∥F​​≤2E∥Rn​∥F​≤2n2log(2E[∣Fx1n​​])​​≤2n2log(2supx1n​​∣Fx1n​​∣)​​where ΠF​(n)=x1n​sup​∣Fx1n​​∣=2n2log(2ΠF​(n))​​.​(3)​

If ΠF(n)=2n\Pi_\mathcal{F}(n) = 2^nΠF​(n)=2n, this bound is trivial. But if n>VC(F)n>VC(\mathcal{F})n>VC(F), then ΠF(n)<2n\Pi_\mathcal{F}(n)<2^nΠF​(n)<2n. In fact, it turns out that ΠF(n)\Pi_{\mathcal{F}}(n)ΠF​(n) will be much smaller than 2n2^n2n!

Lemma (Sauer's lemma). Fix d≥VC(F)d\geq VC(\mathcal{F})d≥VC(F). It holds that
ΠF(n)≤∑k=0min⁡{n,d}(nk).\Pi_\mathcal{F}(n) \leq \sum_{k=0}^{\min\{ n,d \}} {n \choose k}.ΠF​(n)≤k=0∑min{n,d}​(kn​).

Hence,
ΠF(n)≤{2n,n≤d(ed)dnd,n>d.\Pi_\mathcal{F}(n) \leq \begin{cases} 2^n, & n\leq d \\ \left( \frac{e}{d} \right)^d n^d, & n>d. \end{cases}ΠF​(n)≤{2n,(de​)dnd,​n≤dn>d.​


By (3)\red{(3)}(3), the above implies that, if n>d≥VC(F)n>d\geq VC(\mathcal{F})n>d≥VC(F) and F\mathcal{F}F consists of boolean-valued functions, then
E∥Pn−P∥F≤22log⁡(2)+2dlog⁡(ed⋅n)n=O(log⁡(n)n).\begin{align*} E \Vert P_n - P\Vert_\mathcal{F} &\leq 2 \sqrt{\frac{2\log(2) + 2d\log\left( \frac{e}{d} \cdot n \right)}{n}} \\ &= O \left( \sqrt{\frac{\log(n)}{n}} \right). \end{align*}E∥Pn​−P∥F​​≤2n2log(2)+2dlog(de​⋅n)​​=O(nlog(n)​​).​

Some things to note:

  • The above is helpful for deriving regret bounds for ERMs when the loss is boolean-valued.
  • But: for general R\mathbb{R}R-valued losses, it's not helpful.

Example: Functions that are Lipschitz in their indexing parameter.

Let f:X×B→Rf: \mathcal{X} \times B \to \mathbb{R}f:X×B→R be some function and
{x↦f(x,β):β∈B}.\left\{ x\mapsto f(x,\beta): \beta\in B \right\}.{x↦f(x,β):β∈B}.

For example, f(x,β)=[y−β⊤w]2f(x,\beta) = [y-\beta^\top w]^2f(x,β)=[y−β⊤w]2 with x=(w,y)x=(w,y)x=(w,y) and BBB a bounded set of Rp\mathbb{R}^pRp.

Suppose that fff satisfies the following Lipschitz condition:

    There exists L>0L>0L>0 such that, for all β1,β2∈B\beta_1,\beta_2 \in Bβ1​,β2​∈B,
    ∥f(⋅,β1)−f(⋅,β2)∥F≤L∥β1−β2∥B,\Vert f(\cdot, \beta_1) - f(\cdot, \beta_2) \Vert_\mathcal{F} \leq L \Vert \beta_1 - \beta_2 \Vert_B,∥f(⋅,β1​)−f(⋅,β2​)∥F​≤L∥β1​−β2​∥B​,

    where ∥⋅∥F\Vert \cdot \Vert_\mathcal{F}∥⋅∥F​ is a norm on F\mathcal{F}F and ∥⋅∥B\Vert \cdot \Vert_B∥⋅∥B​ is a norm on BBB.

Claim: N(ε,F,∥⋅∥F)≤N(εL,B,∥⋅∥B)N(\varepsilon, \mathcal{F}, \Vert \cdot \Vert_{\mathcal{F}}) \leq N\left( \frac{\varepsilon}{L}, B, \Vert \cdot \Vert_B \right)N(ε,F,∥⋅∥F​)≤N(Lε​,B,∥⋅∥B​).


Proof. Let {βj}j=1n\{ \beta_j \}_{j=1}^{n}{βj​}j=1n​ denote a minimal εL\frac{\varepsilon}{L}Lε​ cover of BBB, so that n=N(εL,B,∥⋅∥B)n=N\left( \frac{\varepsilon}{L}, B, \Vert \cdot \Vert_B \right)n=N(Lε​,B,∥⋅∥B​). We'll show that {f(⋅,βj)}j=1n\{ f(\cdot, \beta_j) \}_{j=1}^{n}{f(⋅,βj​)}j=1n​ is an ε\varepsilonε-cover of F\mathcal{F}F.

Fix g∈Fg\in\mathcal{F}g∈F and let β∈B\beta\in Bβ∈B be such that g(⋅)=f(⋅,β)g(\cdot) = f(\cdot,\beta)g(⋅)=f(⋅,β). Let βj\beta_jβj​ be such that ∥βj−β∥B≤εL\Vert \beta_j - \beta \Vert_B \leq \frac{\varepsilon}{L}∥βj​−β∥B​≤Lε​. Combining this with the Lipschitz-condition\blue{\text{Lipschitz-condition}}Lipschitz-condition gives
∥f(⋅,β)−f(⋅,βj)∥F≤L∥β−βj∥B≤L⋅εL=ε.\begin{align*} \Vert f(\cdot, \beta) - f(\cdot, \beta_j) \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} &\leq L \Vert \beta-\beta_j \Vert_B \\ &\leq L \cdot \frac{\varepsilon}{L} \\ &= \varepsilon. \end{align*}∥f(⋅,β)−f(⋅,βj​)∥F​​≤L∥β−βj​∥B​≤L⋅Lε​=ε.​


Recall: ∥f∥∞:=sup⁡x∣f(x)∣\Vert f \Vert_\infty := \sup_x |f(x)|∥f∥∞​:=supx​∣f(x)∣.

Theorem. Let F⊂Lr(P)F \subset L^r(P)F⊂Lr(P), r∈[1,∞]r\in[1,\infty]r∈[1,∞]. For ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0,
N[](2ε,F,Lr(P))≤N(ε,F,∥⋅∥∞).N_{[]}(2\varepsilon, \mathcal{F}, L^r(P)) \leq N(\varepsilon, \mathcal{F}, \Vert \cdot \Vert_{\infty}).N[]​(2ε,F,Lr(P))≤N(ε,F,∥⋅∥∞​).


Proof. Let {fj}j=1n\{ f_j \}_{j=1}^{n}{fj​}j=1n​ denote a minimal ε\varepsilonε-cover of F\mathcal{F}F, so that n=N(ε,F,∥⋅∥∞)n=N(\varepsilon,\mathcal{F}, \Vert \cdot \Vert_\infty)n=N(ε,F,∥⋅∥∞​). For each j∈{1,2,…,n}j\in\{ 1,2,\dots,n \}j∈{1,2,…,n}, define the 2ε2\varepsilon2ε-bracket
[fj−ε,fj+ε].[f_j - \varepsilon, f_j + \varepsilon].[fj​−ε,fj​+ε].

Why is this a 2ε2\varepsilon2ε-bracket?
∥fj+ε−(fj−ε)∥Lr(P)=∥2ε∥L(P)=2ε.\Vert f_j + \varepsilon - (f_j - \varepsilon) \Vert_{L^r(P)} = \Vert 2\varepsilon \Vert_{L^(P)} = 2\varepsilon.∥fj​+ε−(fj​−ε)∥Lr(P)​=∥2ε∥L(P)​=2ε.

Because {fj}j=1n\{ f_j \}_{j=1}^{n}{fj​}j=1n​ is an ε\varepsilonε-cover of F\mathcal{F}F relative to ∥⋅∥∞\Vert\cdot \Vert_\infty∥⋅∥∞​, it holds that
F⊆⋃j=1n[fj−ε,fj+ε].\mathcal{F}\subseteq \bigcup_{j=1}^{n} [f_j-\varepsilon, f_j+\varepsilon].F⊆j=1⋃n​[fj​−ε,fj​+ε].

Hence, we've exhibited a collection of nnn 2ε2\varepsilon2ε-brackets that covers F\mathcal{F}F.


Reminder: To control the regret of an empirical risk minimizer, it's enough to control E∥Pn−P∥F≤2E∥Rn∥FE\Vert P_n-P \Vert_\mathcal{F}\leq 2E\Vert R_n\Vert_\mathcal{F}E∥Pn​−P∥F​≤2E∥Rn​∥F​.



Stochastic Process

  • A stochastic process\textcolor{blue}{\text{stochastic process}}stochastic process {Xθ:θ∈T}\{ X_\theta:\theta\in T \}{Xθ​:θ∈T} is a collection of random variables.
  • A process is called mean zero\textcolor{blue}{\text{mean zero}}mean zero if E[Xθ]=0E[X_\theta] = 0E[Xθ​]=0 for all θ∈T\theta\in Tθ∈T.
  • We'll find it useful to be able to say that Xθ1 is “close" to Xθ2\textcolor{purple}{X_{\theta_1} \text{ is ``close" to } X_{\theta_2}}Xθ1​​ is “close" to Xθ2​​ is θ1 is “close" to θ2\textcolor{purple}{{\theta_1} \text{ is ``close" to } {\theta_2}}θ1​ is “close" to θ2​ in some appropriate sense.
  • To formalize this, we define the notion of a sub-Gaussian process\textcolor{blue}{\text{sub-Gaussian process}}sub-Gaussian process.

Definition. A mean zero stochastic process is called sub-Gaussian with respect to d\textcolor{blue}{\text{sub-Gaussian with respect to } d}sub-Gaussian with respect to d, with ddd a pseudometric on TTT, if, for all θ,θ′∈T\theta,\theta'\in Tθ,θ′∈T and λ∈R\lambda\in\mathbb{R}λ∈R,
log⁡E[exp⁡{λ(Xθ−Xθ′)}]≤λ2d(θ,θ′)22.\log E \left[ \exp \left\{ \lambda (X_\theta - X_{\theta'}) \right\} \right] \leq \frac{\lambda^2 d(\theta, \theta')^2}{2}.logE[exp{λ(Xθ​−Xθ′​)}]≤2λ2d(θ,θ′)2​.


Equivalent definition: A mean zero stochastic process is called sub-Gaussian with respect to ddd if, for all θ,θ′∈T\theta,\theta'\in Tθ,θ′∈T, Xθ−Xθ′X_\theta - X_{\theta'}Xθ​−Xθ′​ is sub-Gaussian with parameter d(θ,θ′)2d(\theta,\theta')^2d(θ,θ′)2.


Example: Canonical Rademacher Process.

  • Let S=RnS=\mathbb{R}^nS=Rn and ddd denote the Euclidean metric on SSS.

  • Let T⊆ST\subseteq ST⊆S denote the index set.

  • Let r1,r2,…,rnr_1,r_2,\dots,r_nr1​,r2​,…,rn​ denote iid Rademacher random variables.

  • The canonical Rademacher process\textcolor{blue}{\text{canonical Rademacher process}}canonical Rademacher process {Xθ:θ∈T}\{ X_\theta: \theta\in T \}{Xθ​:θ∈T} is define so that
    Xθ=∑j=1nθjrj=⟨θ,r⟩,X_\theta = \sum_{j=1}^{n} \theta_j r_j = \langle \theta, r \rangle,Xθ​=j=1∑n​θj​rj​=⟨θ,r⟩,

    where r=(r1,…,rn)r=(r_1,\dots,r_n)r=(r1​,…,rn​).

  • Using results from Chapter 3, you can show {Xθ:θ∈T}\{ X_\theta: \theta\in T \}{Xθ​:θ∈T} is sub-Gaussian with respect to the Euclidean metric ddd.

  • Why is this process relevant to us?

    • When T=Fx1n⋃(−Fz1n)T=\mathcal{F}_{x_1^n} \bigcup (- \mathcal{F}_{z_1^n})T=Fx1n​​⋃(−Fz1n​​) (where z1nz_1^nz1n​ is a generic realization of Z1,Z2,…,Zn∼iidPZ_1,Z_2,\dots,Z_n \stackrel{iid}{\sim} PZ1​,Z2​,…,Zn​∼iidP), we'll show that
      E[∥Rn∥F∣Z1n=z1n]=1nE[sup⁡θ∈TXθ].E [\Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} \mid Z_1^n = z_1^n] = \frac{1}{n} E \left[ \sup_{\theta\in T} X_\theta \right].E[∥Rn​∥F​∣Z1n​=z1n​]=n1​E[θ∈Tsup​Xθ​].

Lemma (Finite class lemma). If {Xθ:θ∈T}\{ X_\theta: \theta\in T \}{Xθ​:θ∈T} is sub-Gaussian with respect to ddd and A⊆T×TA\subseteq T\times TA⊆T×T, then
E[max⁡(θ,θ′)∈A(Xθ−Xθ′)]≤2log⁡∣A∣max⁡(θ,θ′)∈Ad(θ,θ′)⏟“the diameter of A"E \left[ \max_{(\theta,\theta') \in A} (X_\theta - X_{\theta'}) \right] \leq \sqrt{2\log |A|} \underbrace{{\max_{(\theta,\theta')\in A} d(\theta, \theta')}}_{\purple{\text{``the diameter of } A "}}E[(θ,θ′)∈Amax​(Xθ​−Xθ′​)]≤2log∣A∣​“the diameter of A"(θ,θ′)∈Amax​d(θ,θ′)​​


Theorem (one-step discretization bound). Let {Xθ:θ∈T}\{ X_\theta: \theta\in T \}{Xθ​:θ∈T} denote a mean zero sub-Gaussian process with respect to ddd. Let D:=sup⁡θ,θ′∈Td(θ,θ′)D:= \sup_{\theta,\theta'\in T} d(\theta, \theta')D:=supθ,θ′∈T​d(θ,θ′) denote the diameter of TTT. For any ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0,
E[sup⁡θ∈TXθ]≤2E[sup⁡(θ,θ′)∈T:d(θ,θ′)≤ε(Xθ−Xθ′)]+2Dlog⁡N(ε,T,d).E \left[ \sup_{\theta\in T} X_\theta \right] \leq 2 E \left[ \pink{\sup_{(\theta,\theta')\in T: d(\theta,\theta')\leq \varepsilon} (X_\theta - X_{\theta'})} \right] + \blue{2D \sqrt{\log N(\varepsilon, T, d)}}.E[θ∈Tsup​Xθ​]≤2E[(θ,θ′)∈T:d(θ,θ′)≤εsup​(Xθ​−Xθ′​)]+2DlogN(ε,T,d)​.

Note that as ε↓0\blue{\varepsilon \downarrow 0}ε↓0, we have
sup⁡(θ,θ′)∈T:d(θ,θ′)≤ε(Xθ−Xθ′)      ↘\displaystyle \pink{\sup_{(\theta,\theta')\in T: d(\theta,\theta')\leq \varepsilon} (X_\theta - X_{\theta'})} \;\;\;{\large \searrow}(θ,θ′)∈T:d(θ,θ′)≤εsup​(Xθ​−Xθ′​)↘

and
2Dlog⁡N(ε,T,d)      ↗\displaystyle \blue{2D \sqrt{\log N(\varepsilon, T, d)}}\;\;\;{\nearrow}2DlogN(ε,T,d)​↗


Proof. For any θ′∈T\theta'\in Tθ′∈T, the fact that {Xθ:θ∈T}\{ X_\theta: \theta\in T \}{Xθ​:θ∈T} is mean zero implies that
E[sup⁡θ∈TXθ]=E[sup⁡θ∈T(Xθ−Xθ′)]≤E[sup⁡θ,θ′∈T(Xθ−Xθ′)].\begin{align*} E \left[ \sup_{\theta\in T} X_\theta \right] &= E \left[ \sup_{\theta\in T} (X_\theta - X_{\theta'}) \right] \\ &\leq E \left[ \sup_{\theta,\theta'\in T} (\blue{X_\theta - X_{\theta'} }) \right]. \end{align*}E[θ∈Tsup​Xθ​]​=E[θ∈Tsup​(Xθ​−Xθ′​)]≤E[θ,θ′∈Tsup​(Xθ​−Xθ′​)].​

Let T1T_1T1​ denote a minimal ε\varepsilonε-cover of TTT. For any θ,θ′∈T\theta,\theta'\in Tθ,θ′∈T, there exist θ1,θ1′∈T1\theta_1, \theta_1' \in T_1θ1​,θ1′​∈T1​ such that d(θ,θ1)≤εd(\theta,\theta_1) \leq \varepsilond(θ,θ1​)≤ε and d(θ′,θ1′)≤εd(\theta', \theta_1') \leq \varepsilond(θ′,θ1′​)≤ε. Observe that
Xθ−Xθ′=(Xθ−Xθ1)−(Xθ′−Xθ1′)+(Xθ1−Xθ1′)≤2sup⁡θ2,θ3∈T:d(θ2,θ3)≤ε(Xθ2−Xθ3)+max⁡(θ4,θ5)∈T1×T1(Xθ4−Xθ5).\begin{align*} \blue {X_\theta - X_{\theta'}} &= (X_\theta - X_{\theta_1}) - (X_{\theta'} - X_{\theta_1'}) + (X_{\theta_1} - X_{\theta_1'}) \\ &\leq 2 \sup_{\theta_2,\theta_3\in T: d(\theta_2, \theta_3) \leq \varepsilon} (X_{\theta_2} - X_{\theta_3}) + \max_{(\theta_4, \theta_5)\in T_1\times T_1} (X_{\theta_4} - X_{\theta_5}). \end{align*}Xθ​−Xθ′​​=(Xθ​−Xθ1​​)−(Xθ′​−Xθ1′​​)+(Xθ1​​−Xθ1′​​)≤2θ2​,θ3​∈T:d(θ2​,θ3​)≤εsup​(Xθ2​​−Xθ3​​)+(θ4​,θ5​)∈T1​×T1​max​(Xθ4​​−Xθ5​​).​

Combining the above two displays, we have,
E[sup⁡θ∈TXθ]≤2E[sup⁡θ2,θ3∈T:d(θ2,θ3)≤ε(Xθ2−Xθ3)]+E[max⁡(θ4,θ5)∈T1×T1(Xθ4−Xθ5)]⏟(★).E \left[ \sup_{\theta\in T} X_\theta \right] \leq 2 E \left[ \sup_{\theta_2, \theta_3\in T: d(\theta_2,\theta_3) \leq \varepsilon} (X_{\theta_2} - X_{\theta_3}) \right] + \underbrace{E \left[ \max_{(\theta_4, \theta_5)\in T_1\times T_1} (X_{\theta_4} - X_{\theta_5}) \right]}_{\red{(\bigstar)}}.E[θ∈Tsup​Xθ​]≤2E[θ2​,θ3​∈T:d(θ2​,θ3​)≤εsup​(Xθ2​​−Xθ3​​)]+(★)E[(θ4​,θ5​)∈T1​×T1​max​(Xθ4​​−Xθ5​​)]​​.

By the finite class lemma,
(★)≤(2log⁡∣T1×T1∣)1/2D=2(log⁡∣T1∣)1/2D=2log⁡N(ε,T,d)D.\begin{align*} \red{(\bigstar)} &\leq \left( 2 \log | T_1\times T_1| \right)^{1/2} D \\ &= 2 \left( \log |T_1| \right)^{1/2} D \\ &= 2 \sqrt{ \log N(\varepsilon, T, d)} D. \end{align*}(★)​≤(2log∣T1​×T1​∣)1/2D=2(log∣T1​∣)1/2D=2logN(ε,T,d)​D.​


We'll now use the one-step discretization bound to establish the following result:

Theorem. If F\mathcal{F}F is a class of functions whose ranges are bounded in [−M,M][-M, M][−M,M], for for any δ>0\delta>0δ>0, we have
E∥Rn∥F≤2δ+4Mn−1/2sup⁡Qlog⁡[2N(δ,F,L2(Q))],E \Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} \leq 2\delta + 4Mn^{-1/2} \sup_Q \sqrt{ \log[2N(\delta, \mathcal{F}, L^2(Q))]},E∥Rn​∥F​≤2δ+4Mn−1/2Qsup​log[2N(δ,F,L2(Q))]​,

where the supremum is over all finitely supported distributions whose support is contained in that of PPP.

Proof.

  • Step 1: Relating the Rademacher complexity of F\mathcal{F}F to the expected supremum of a sub-Gaussian process.

    Recall:
    Fz1n:={(f(z1),f(z2),…,f(zn)):f∈F}.\mathcal{F}_{z_1^n} := \left\{ (f(z_1), f(z_2), \dots, f(z_n)): f\in\mathcal{F} \right\}.Fz1n​​:={(f(z1​),f(z2​),…,f(zn​)):f∈F}.

    Let T:=Fz1n∪(−Fz1n)T:= \mathcal{F}_{z_1^n} \cup (-\mathcal{F}_{z_1^n})T:=Fz1n​​∪(−Fz1n​​). We consider the canonical Rademacher process
    {Xθ:=∑j=1nθjrj:θ∈T⊆Rn},\left\{ X_\theta := \sum_{j=1}^{n} \theta_j r_j : \theta\in T\subseteq \mathbb{R}^n \right\},{Xθ​:=j=1∑n​θj​rj​:θ∈T⊆Rn},

    noting that ∑j=1nθjrj=:⟨θ,r⟩\sum_{j=1}^{n} \theta_j r_j =: \langle \theta, r \rangle∑j=1n​θj​rj​=:⟨θ,r⟩.

    The empirical Rademacher complexity rewrites as follows:
    E[∥Rn∥F∣Z1n=z1n]=E[sup⁡f∈F∣1n∑j=1nf(Zj)rj∣ ∣Z1n=z1n]=1nE[sup⁡f∈F∣⟨f(z1n),r⟩∣∣Z1n=z1n]=1nE[sup⁡f∈F∪(−F)⟨f(z1n),r⟩∣Z1n=z1n]=1nE[sup⁡θ∈TXθ].\begin{align*} E \left[ \Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} \mid Z_1^n = z_1^n \right] &= E \left[ \left. \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} f(Z_j) r_j \right| \, \right| Z_1^n = z_1^n \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{n} E \left[ \left. \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F}} \left| \langle f(z_1^n), r \rangle \right| \right| Z_1^n = z_1^n \right] \\ &= \frac{1}{n} E \left[ \left. \sup_{f\in\mathcal{F} \cup (-\mathcal{F})} \langle f(z_1^n), r \rangle \right| Z_1^n = z_1^n \right] \tag*{\small$\langle f(z_1^n), r \rangle = X_\theta$ with $\theta=f(z_1^n)$\normalsize}\\ &= \frac{1}{n} E \left[ \sup_{\theta\in T} X_\theta \right]. \end{align*}E[∥Rn​∥F​∣Z1n​=z1n​]​=E[f∈Fsup​​n1​j=1∑n​f(Zj​)rj​​​Z1n​=z1n​]=n1​E[f∈Fsup​∣⟨f(z1n​),r⟩∣​Z1n​=z1n​]=n1​E[f∈F∪(−F)sup​⟨f(z1n​),r⟩​Z1n​=z1n​]=n1​E[θ∈Tsup​Xθ​].​⟨f(z1n​),r⟩=Xθ​ with θ=f(z1n​)​

  • Step 2: Applying the one-step discretization bound to E[sup⁡θ∈TXθ]\displaystyle E\left[ \sup_{\theta\in T} X_\theta \right]E[θ∈Tsup​Xθ​].

    By that bound, for any ε>0\varepsilon>0ε>0,
    E[sup⁡θ∈TXθ]≤2E[sup⁡θ,θ′∈T:d(θ,θ′)≤ε(Xθ−Xθ′)]+2Dlog⁡N(ε,T,d),\red{\boxed{E\left[ \sup_{\theta\in T} X_\theta \right] \leq 2 E \left[ \sup_{\theta,\theta'\in T: d(\theta,\theta')\leq \varepsilon} (X_\theta - X_{\theta'}) \right] + 2D \sqrt{\log N(\varepsilon, T, d)}}},E[θ∈Tsup​Xθ​]≤2E[θ,θ′∈T:d(θ,θ′)≤εsup​(Xθ​−Xθ′​)]+2DlogN(ε,T,d)​​,

    where ddd is the Euclidean metric in this case.

    In the remainder of our argument, we study the two terms on the right hand side.

    For the first,
    E[sup⁡θ,θ′∈T:d(θ,θ′)≤ε(Xθ−Xθ′)]=E[sup⁡θ,θ′∈T:d(θ,θ′)≤ε⟨θ−θ′,r⟩]≤E[sup⁡θ,θ′∈Rn:d(θ,θ′)≤ε⟨θ−θ′,r⟩]=E[⟨v,r⟩∣v=εr/∥r∥]=εE[∥r∥2]=εn1/2.\begin{align*} E\left[ \sup_{\theta, \theta' \in T: d(\theta,\theta')\leq \varepsilon} (X_\theta - X_{\theta'}) \right] &= E \left[ \sup_{\theta, \theta' \in T: d(\theta,\theta')\leq \varepsilon} \langle \theta-\theta', r \rangle \right] \\ &\leq E \left[ \sup_{\theta,\theta'\in\mathbb{R}^n: d(\theta,\theta')\leq \varepsilon} \langle \theta-\theta', r \rangle \right] \\ &= E \left[ \langle v,r \rangle |_{v=\varepsilon r / \Vert r \Vert} \right] \\ &= \varepsilon E \left[ \Vert r \Vert_2 \right] \\ &= \varepsilon n^{1/2}. \end{align*}E[θ,θ′∈T:d(θ,θ′)≤εsup​(Xθ​−Xθ′​)]​=E[θ,θ′∈T:d(θ,θ′)≤εsup​⟨θ−θ′,r⟩]≤E[θ,θ′∈Rn:d(θ,θ′)≤εsup​⟨θ−θ′,r⟩]=E[⟨v,r⟩∣v=εr/∥r∥​]=εE[∥r∥2​]=εn1/2.​

    Pluggin this into  our earlier bound ,
    E[sup⁡θ∈TXθ]≤2εn1/2+2Dlog⁡N(ε,T,∥⋅∥2).E\left[ \sup_{\theta\in T} X_\theta \right] \leq 2\varepsilon n^{1/2} + 2D \sqrt{\log N(\varepsilon, T, \Vert \cdot \Vert_2)}.E[θ∈Tsup​Xθ​]≤2εn1/2+2DlogN(ε,T,∥⋅∥2​)​.

    Recalling step 1, we've shown
    E[∥Rn∥F∣Z1n=z1n]≤2εn−1/2+2n−1Dlog⁡N(ε,T,∥⋅∥2).\textcolor{#fc9300}{\boxed{E\left[ \Vert R_n \Vert_\mathcal{F} | Z_1^n = z_1^n \right] \leq 2 \varepsilon n^{-1/2} + 2n^{-1} D\sqrt{\log N(\varepsilon, T, \Vert \cdot \Vert_2)}}}.E[∥Rn​∥F​∣Z1n​=z1n​]≤2εn−1/2+2n−1DlogN(ε,T,∥⋅∥2​)​​.

  • Step 3: Find a bound in terms of the covering number of F\mathcal{F}F.

    To do this, we relate the covering numbers of F\mathcal{F}F to those of T:=Fz1n∪(−Fz1n)T:= \mathcal{F}_{z_1^n} \cup (-\mathcal{F}_{z_1^n})T:=Fz1n​​∪(−Fz1n​​).

    • Fix θ1,θ2∈T\theta_1,\theta_2\in Tθ1​,θ2​∈T. There exist f1,f2∈F∪(−F)f_1,f_2\in \mathcal{F}\cup (-\mathcal{F})f1​,f2​∈F∪(−F) such that θ1=(f1(z1),…,f1(zn))\theta_1 = (f_1(z_1), \dots, f_1(z_n))θ1​=(f1​(z1​),…,f1​(zn​)) and θ2=(f2(z1),…,f2(zn))\theta_2 = (f_2(z_1), \dots, f_2(z_n))θ2​=(f2​(z1​),…,f2​(zn​)). Hence,
      ∥θ1−θ2∥=∑i=1n[θ1i−θ2i]2=∑i=1n[f1(zi)−f2(zi)]2=n1/21n∑i=1n[f1(zi)−f2(zi)]2=n1/2∥f1−f2∥L2(Pn),\begin{align*} \Vert \theta_1 - \theta_2 \Vert &= \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^n [\theta_{1i} - \theta_{2i}]^2} \\ &= \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n} [f_1(z_i) - f_2(z_i)]^2} \\ &= n^{1/2} \sqrt{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n [f_1(z_i) - f_2(z_i)]^2} \\ &= n^{1/2} \Vert f_1 - f_2 \Vert_{L^2(P_n)}, \end{align*}∥θ1​−θ2​∥​=i=1∑n​[θ1i​−θ2i​]2​=i=1∑n​[f1​(zi​)−f2​(zi​)]2​=n1/2n1​i=1∑n​[f1​(zi​)−f2​(zi​)]2​=n1/2∥f1​−f2​∥L2(Pn​)​,​

      where PnP_nPn​ denotes the empirical distribution when Z1n=z1nZ_1^n = z_1^nZ1n​=z1n​.

      Using the above,
      N(ε,T,∥⋅∥2)=N(εn−1/2,F∪(−F),L2(Pn)).N ( \varepsilon, T, \Vert \cdot \Vert_2) = N\left(\varepsilon n^{-1/2}, \mathcal{F} \cup (-\mathcal{F}), L^2(P_n) \right).N(ε,T,∥⋅∥2​)=N(εn−1/2,F∪(−F),L2(Pn​)).

    • Plugging this into  step 2 ,
      E[∥Rn∥F∣Z1n=z1n]≤2n−1/2ε+2Dn−1log⁡N(εn−1/2,F∪(−F),L2(Pn))≤2n−1/2ε+2Dn−1sup⁡Qlog⁡N(εn−1/2,F∪(−F),L2(Q))=2δ+2Dn−1sup⁡Qlog⁡N(δ,F∪(−F),L2(Pn)),\begin{align*} E \left[ \Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} | Z_1^n=z_1^n \right] &\leq 2 n^{-1/2} \varepsilon + 2 D n^{-1} \sqrt{\log N\left( \varepsilon n^{-1/2}, \mathcal{F}\cup (-\mathcal{F}), L^2(P_n) \right)} \\ &\leq 2 n^{-1/2} \varepsilon + 2 D n^{-1} \sup_{Q}\sqrt{\log N\left( \varepsilon n^{-1/2}, \mathcal{F}\cup (-\mathcal{F}), L^2(Q) \right)} \\ &= 2\delta + 2Dn^{-1} \sup_Q \sqrt{\log N\left( \delta, \mathcal{F}\cup (-\mathcal{F}), L^2(P_n) \right)}, \end{align*}E[∥Rn​∥F​∣Z1n​=z1n​]​≤2n−1/2ε+2Dn−1logN(εn−1/2,F∪(−F),L2(Pn​))​≤2n−1/2ε+2Dn−1Qsup​logN(εn−1/2,F∪(−F),L2(Q))​=2δ+2Dn−1Qsup​logN(δ,F∪(−F),L2(Pn​))​,​

      where δ=ε/n\delta=\varepsilon/\sqrt{n}δ=ε/n​. Above, the supremum is over all finitely supported distributions whose support is contained in that of P\mathcal{P}P.

      We now make the dependence of our diameter DDD on z1nz_1^nz1n​ explicit in the notation by writing Dz1nD_{z_1^n}Dz1n​​.

      Using that functions in F\mathcal{F}F are bounded in [−M,M][-M, M][−M,M],
      Dz1n:=sup⁡θ1,θ2∈Fz1n∪(−Fz1n)∥θ1−θ2∥2=sup⁡f1,f2∈F∪(−F)∥f1−f2∥L2(Pn)n1/2≤2Mn1/2.\begin{align*} D_{z_1^n} &:= \sup_{\theta_1,\theta_2\in \mathcal{F}_{z_1^n} \cup (-\mathcal{F}_{z_1^n})} \Vert \theta_1 - \theta_2 \Vert_2 \\ &= \sup_{f_1,f_2\in \mathcal{F}\cup (-\mathcal{F})} \Vert f_1 - f_2 \Vert_{L^2(P_n)} n^{1/2} \\ &\leq 2Mn^{1/2}. \end{align*}Dz1n​​​:=θ1​,θ2​∈Fz1n​​∪(−Fz1n​​)sup​∥θ1​−θ2​∥2​=f1​,f2​∈F∪(−F)sup​∥f1​−f2​∥L2(Pn​)​n1/2≤2Mn1/2.​

    • Lastly, we note that
      N(δ,F∪(−F),L2(Q))≤2N(δ,F,L2(Q)).N(\delta, \mathcal{F}\cup (-\mathcal{F}), L^2(Q)) \leq 2N(\delta, \mathcal{F}, L^2(Q)).N(δ,F∪(−F),L2(Q))≤2N(δ,F,L2(Q)).

      Putting everything together, we have
      E[∥Rn∥F∣Z1n=z1n]≤2δ+4Mn−1/2sup⁡Qlog⁡[2N(δ,F,L2(Q))].E \left[ \Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} | Z_1^n = z_1^n \right] \leq 2\delta + 4Mn^{-1/2} \sup_Q \sqrt{\log[2 N(\delta, \mathcal{F}, L^2(Q))]}.E[∥Rn​∥F​∣Z1n​=z1n​]≤2δ+4Mn−1/2Qsup​log[2N(δ,F,L2(Q))]​.

      Integrating both sides against PnP^nPn gives our desired bound on E[∥Rn∥F]E\left[ \Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} \right]E[∥Rn​∥F​].



Motivation for Dudley's entropy integral bound.

Recall that the one-step discretization bound show that
E[∥Rn∥F]≤2δ+4Mn−1/2sup⁡Qlog⁡[2N(δ,F,L2(Q))].E\left[ \Vert R_n \Vert_{\mathcal{F}} \right] \leq 2\delta + 4Mn^{-1/2} \sup_Q \sqrt{\log[2 N(\delta, \mathcal{F}, L^2(Q))]}.E[∥Rn​∥F​]≤2δ+4Mn−1/2Qsup​log[2N(δ,F,L2(Q))]​.

A key observation made by Dudley is that, if F\mathcal{F}F isn't "too big" in an appropriate sense, the latter term above can be replaced by a term that doesn't go to +∞+\infty+∞ as δ↓0\delta \downarrow 0δ↓0.
